text: CLOSE SHOT -- station signboard. It reads:

CAMERA PANS to show the dusty platform of a typical small Arizona town of the late nineties. CAMERA TRUCKS ALONG platform PAST a line of sleeping figu consisting of a couple of drunks, an Indian, two Mexicans and a mongrel dog. CAMERA STOPS on the window of the ticket office. Inside t office can be glimpsed the Station Agent dozing in a chai with his feet up against the grill of the ticket window. clicking of the signal indicator is heard. The agent open his eyes, flips up the indicator and begins to get to his feet sleepily.
line of sleeping figures, with dog in f.g. The sound of a distant train whistle is heard o.s. The dog, which up to might have been dead, opens one eye and looks past camera
railway track with the three-car train approaching.

line of sleeping figures. The dog jumps up barking furiou and runs out of shot past camera. The sleeping figures co to life and look toward camera. At the same time, the doo of the ticket office opens and the agent appears.
railway track. The train is now almost at the station.

FULL SHOT -- with the line of men now standing on the edg of the platform looking toward camera. Train steams slowl in past camera, and stops, with a tall, wide-shouldered m of about 28 (Rocklin), dressed in new store clothes, cowb and a broad-brimmed white hat, in f. g. standing on steps day coach with a small valise and saddle in his hands. Be Rocklin a conductor.
baggage car. The baggageman is standing at the open door the car with two sacks of mail. He drops them to the plat and waves to the conductor o.s. and begins to close the d of the baggage car.
on Station Agent and conductors. The latter signals the  engineer. The train whistle sounds again o.s. and the sha of the moving train begins to pass across the Station Age face.

As Rocklin comes along the platform carrying the valise i one hand and balancing the saddle on his shoulder with th other, a man behind him picks up the two mail sacks and e from scene. The station bums look at Rocklin curiously. H expression giving no encouragement, they slink back out o the sun and begin to settle down in their old places agai At the ticket office, Rocklin pauses and looks around  uncertainly.
(at office door) Expectin' someone?
(after a second's  pause) I guess not. Where's the stagecoach  office?
(pointing) Back of the depot.
The stage is drawn up in front of the depot, over which i sign --
J. Harolday Proprietor

Rocklin, making his way along the walk, almost reaches th depot when his attention is arrested by the sight of Dave the stage driver, who has just rounded in front of the le horses. He pauses close to one horse's head. Rocklin sees Dave take a bottle from his person, uncork it as he glanc around, and raise it to drink. The bottle is almost to Da lips when the horse shies, swinging its head. The bottle knocked from the old fellow's hands and smashes on the gr Now Rocklin witnesses a scene of intense fury, which he f amusing despite its seriousness. Old Dave rants and snort beats his thighs, his heads, flings his arms wildly and  exhibits his utter disgust generally.

(to horse) Consarn you, Blossom -- lookit that --  jus' lookit what you done -- (some more pantomime) I'm tellin' you, Blossom that -- (indicating broken  bottle) -- makes you the most aggravatin'  female as ever I had a despise fer --  I've got a good notion to pizen you --  an' what's more --

He stops talking abruptly because his hand has, quite by  chance, felt the spare bottle he carries, which he has  forgotten in his anger. A most satisfying smile lights hi bewhiskered face as he brings the bottle into view. He un it, and stepping a few paces from the horse, raises the  bottle.
(to Blossom) Heh-heh -- fooled you, didn't I? -- (chuckles) Fooled myself, too.
who has been watching Dave's performance. He smiles his  amusement and now proceeds toward the stage office.

PAN SHOT. Rocklin enters and moves over to the counter, b which is the stage agent, a mild-looking man with pebble- lens glasses. During the scene, the character who picked the mail sacks from the platform, comes in, dumps the sac on the counter and leaves.
(to Rocklin) Howdy.
(indicating stage) That the stage for Santa Inez?
(nods) Leaving any minute.
Rocklin puts his saddle on the counter, and taking out a of bills, drops them on the counter. The Stage Agent coun out the fare.
Santa Inez -- seventeen-fifty -- (returning the balance) Name?
Rocklin.
The Stage Agent turns to make out the ticket. Rocklin tak some tobacco and paper from his vest pocket as he glances outside.
Mind if I ride alongside the driver?
(over his specs) It's all right with me -- if it's  all right with Dave -- He's mad --  His last trip -- Had a row with  Harolday, the boss -- Old-timer,  Dave -- an' a grumpy old cuss.
(soberly) I like grumpy old cusses -- Hope to  live long enough to be one.
(puzzled) Yeah?
He shakes his head and hands Rocklin the ticket, and move over to the door with one of the mail sacks in his hand.
The Stage Agent, carrying a mail sack, and Rocklin come f the stage depot and reach the stage as Dave is in the act climbing up to the driver's seat.
Here's your mail, Dave --
Dave looks over his shoulder at the Agent and steps to th ground, as Rocklin climbs up to the driver's seat.
(as he steps up to  the seat) -- and a passenger.
Dave glares at Rocklin climbing up to the seat, and he is about to order him down when Rocklin, now seated, looks d at him and asks rather wistfully --
Mind if I ride up here?

Dave does mind, but his better judgment tells him to step carefully in his attitude toward this stranger, who does  things first, then asks permission. His only answer to Ro is a characteristic grimace which is eloquent enough. And now Dave turns on the Agent, who becomes the target of hi pent-up wrath.
Where's them wimmen?
Up at the hotel.
(yanking mail sack  from Agent) Why ain't they here? -- This is the  stage depot, ain't it -- ? (heaves sack into  boot) Ain't it?
You can pick 'em up there -- it's  only up the street --
On'y up the street -- an' they cain't  walk it -- What's the matter -- don't  Easterners have laigs like other  folks?
Dave stalks around the rear of the coach. The Agent meant stretches himself up toward Rocklin.
(so Dave won't hear) Hold tight when you git in the  mountains, mister -- When he gits  riled you can hear the passengers  prayin' for miles.
Dave has climbed to his seat, and now the coach lurches a leaving the Agent shaking his head dubiously.
From the porch of the hotel. We see the stage approaching the hotel handyman brings a trunk and a couple of bags fr the hotel to the street. The coach pulls up and stops.
(to handyman) Whar's them wimmen? -- They waitin'  for you to carry 'em out?

Before the handyman can answer, Dave's attention is taken someone calling his name from across the street. Meantime an Indian squaw wobbles from the hotel with bow and arrow etc. Rocklin buys bow and arrow.
(as he comes to Dave) Dave -- Dave -- tell Arly Harolday  her saddle ain't ready yet, will ya?
(getting to the ground) I ain't tellin' that crazy female  nothin' -- Last time I seen her she  threatened to rip the hide off'n me  and bat me dizzy with it.
Dave goes to the rear of the coach.
(looks up to Rocklin) Mister -- will you tell the Agent at  Santa Inez to tell Miss Harolday her  saddle ain't ready yet?
(nods) I'll say that.

Miss Martin steps out onto the porch followed by Clara an gentleman, presumably the hotel manager or clerk. The wom are obviously Easterners and are attired in the good tast of the period. Miss Martin is a domineering woman, approa middle age. Her niece, Clara, is a well-bred, attractive  girl of twenty-one and completely under the influence of older woman.
(as group comes through  door) By next year, madam, we expect to  have a bathtub on each floor.
Miss Martin stops short and looks o.s.

head_text.subj: ON DAVE AT REAR OF THE COUCH

text: having a time lifting the trunk up into the boot. Miss Ma and the others come into the scene.
Now don't drop it --
Dave pauses to see who is talking.
At your age you'd best not be lifting  things so heavy.
(grimaces) Mebbe you're young enough to hoist  her up your own self. (tries to lift trunk  again)
on Clara. She is looking rather timidly up at Rocklin.
on Rocklin. He is grinning appreciatively at old Dave. No he notices Clara and regards her soberly a moment.
Dave has heaved the trunk in place and is securing it. Miss Martin, about to enter the coach, notices Clara star up at Rocklin.
Clara!
Clara snaps her attention from Rocklin to her aunt. The C steps to the side of the coach and opens the door. He ass Clara inside -- and now Miss Martin.
Miss Martin and Clara. Miss Martin is just sitting. She l coldly at Clara.
(in low voice) Staring as though you'd never seen a  man before.
Dave, Rocklin and Clerk. Dave is at the moment climbing t his seat on the other side of the coach. The Clerk swings the door closed and looks up to Rocklin and speaks more o less confidentially.
Try to hold him down or he'll scare  the women to death.
He is looking down at the Clerk and answers quite casuall but loud enough to be heard by the women.
I never feel sorry for anything that  happens to a woman.

THROUGH window of door -- Miss Martin and Clara. The wome have obviously overheard Rocklin's remark. Miss Martin sm vindictively at Clara, who flushes. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the Clerk, who moves to the  coach door.
Well, I hope you have a nice trip,  ladies.
I hope we get there -- wouldn't  surprise me if we didn't.
On Dave and Rocklin.
(mutters) Wait till I get you on the road, you  old buzzard, you'll be surprised all  right.
He takes up the reins and shouts the team away.

EXTREME LONG SHOT -- with the stage hardly more than a bl dot below, its curl of rising dust in the midst of the wh broad expanse. As the coach disappears from shot, the two mounted men appear riding at an easy pace and continue in the same direction as the coach.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Dave and Rocklin, the latter staring  straight ahead. As they roll with the roll of the coach,  Dave steals a look at his companion.
I wonder why a young feller who don't  have to wants to come into this God  danged country?
Rocklin ignores Dave's question and continues staring ahe Dave glances down toward the women.
Say -- did you mean what you said  back there about wimmen?
(grimly) Every word of it.
(chuckling) Then you're smarter than most.
Maybe I seen more of 'em than most.
(looking at him  admiringly) Shouldn't be surprised. Shouldn't be  a leetle bit surprised. (reflectively) All the same...
He breaks off and chuckles again.
(unsmilingly) All the same -- what?
Dave doesn't reply, but lifting the pint of whiskey, jerk out the cork with one movement of his thumbnail.
(offering bottle to  Rocklin) Take a slug.
Rocklin drinks and gives the bottle back to Dave, who all but empties it in one pull.
(holding up the bottle  and squinting through  it) Whiskey and wimmen -- ever think how  much alike they are? Both fool you,  but you never figger out how to do  without 'em.
Rocklin makes no reply. Dave offers the bottle again.
Take another.
Not just yet.
(unoffended) Well... (putting the bottle  to his lips) Here's to her.
Who?
The next one that fools you.
He empties the bottle and shies it away. At the same time the coach hits a particularly bad patch of road and there muffled exclamation from inside the coach. Dave leans ove and looks down o.s.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Clara and Miss Martin. The former is  showing the effects of the rough ride, but the old lady i hanging on grimly.
Dave straightens up, grinning.
(with relish) Mighty rough stretch along here.
He whips up the team, at the same time weaving a little  unsteadily in his seat.
Like me to speel you a while?
Nope. I've had a few snorts but that  don't make no difference. Leas'ways,  never has... (after a second's  pause) Don't ever git wore out, and useless,  like me.
Who're them as say you are?
Harolday, for one. Oh, I ain't belly- aching. Reckon he's entitled to his  opinion. But him and me never did  see eye to eye.
What's wrong?
It's constitootional, I reckon. Like  that step-daughter of his is crazy --  he's too sane. Believes In law and  order.
(grinning) What's wrong with law and order?
Depends on who's a-dishin' it out.  Never was good at takin' orders  meself. As for the law -- well, you'll  soon find out what that means 'round  these parts.
The coach hits a particularly bad bit of road and there i an exclamation from inside. Dave grins and urges the team cheerfully.
FULL SHOT -- as Dave pulls up the stage at the top of a l downgrade and looks out appreciatively at the view. From  this crest of the rim, a vast expanse of country is visib
stage. Miss Martin thrusts her head out of the window.
Driver? Driver, what's the matter?
Nothin'. Restin' hosses. Git out and  stretch yore laigs if you want.
Resting horses? What for? I can see  with my own eyes it's downhill.
Dave brightens visibly at this challenge.
You in such an all-fired hurry, lady?
Certainly, we are in a hurry.
(beaming) Well -- we'll hurry some.
His whip cracks like a rifle shot and the startled horses literally jerk the heavy stage over the rim and down the  grade.
grade, with the stagecoach bounding and reeling down the  narrow road and around the sharp bends.
Dave and Rocklin on stage as it thunders downhill. Dave i leaning out and listening hopefully for the outcries from within. None come. Rocklin is hanging on with both hands mildly amused.
The two women are really being scrambled.
CLOSE TWO SHOT -- Dave and Rocklin. Rocklin is as calm as he were walking. Dave is more and more pleased with himse He again leans out to listen.
grade, with coach approaching in b.g. In f.g. the road na and makes a sharp turn at the very edge of a precipice. T is no possible way of getting the coach safely around thi turn except at a walk.
road, from point of view of driver's seat, establishing t same menace ahead.
Dave and Rocklin, as Rocklin glances out of the corner of his eyes as if wondering whether or not Dave is too drunk perceive the disaster. He makes no move, however, to advi or interfere.
road; at danger corner, as stage comes in. At the very la second, Dave pulls in the horses and negotiates the turn safety.
stage. Dave grins at Rocklin, then listens for the outcry expects from the women within. The old lady's head bobs o of the window.
(fiercely) Now what's the matter. Why are we  stopping again?
Old Dave's mouth drops open, and as Rocklin begins to gri at his discomfiture.
FULL SHOT of lonely adobe which serves as a combination  roadhouse, stage station and bar. As the coach rolls into f.g., a little Mexican boy (Pablo) runs out to change the horses.
(as Rocklin swings  down) Buenas noches, senor.
Buenas noches, amigo.
(grinning at the  friendly tone) Ha llegado anticipademente, senor.
Tuvimos suerte en haber llegado.
He glances pointedly at Dave who is climbing down unstead and Pablo bursts out laughing.
on door of coach. As Dave comes into shot, Miss Martin's  head pops out of the window.
(gruffly) We stop here.
Why do we stop here?
If you wanta eat and stretch yore  laigs.
Will you please stop referring to my  legs!
You got some, ain't you?
He turns and lurches toward the roadhouse.

FULL SHOT from doorway. It is a large barn-like room on o side of which is a bar. On the other side is a fireplace a partition behind which is a rough dining table and benc Standing at the bar drinking with his back to the door is wizened little man, dressed in an odd assortment of ragge garments of unrecognizable origin. On the counter is a  travelling prospector's pack, to which is strapped an  assortment of prospector's equipment, including a pick an shovel. As Dave enters, the man (Zeke) turns around and  reveals a face even hairier than Dave's.
(holding out his arms) Dave!
(letting out a yell  and rushing to Zeke) Why, Zeke, you two-legged old coot!
Zeke and Dave as they beat one another on the back.
Whar you been all these months?
Up in the hills workin' my way down  the biggest hole you ever seed.
Good -- What's at the bottom of it?
Nothin'!
(roaring with laughter) What, again!!

Rocklin has entered and moved to the fire. Miss Martin an Clara enter and stand in the doorway watching the scene a the bar. A pale-faced, dyspeptic-looking man of about 45  (Stan) comes from the kitchen and approaches them  ingratiatingly.
Good evening, ladies. How about  something to eat?
(with a dubious look  toward the pair at  the bar) Well -- if it won't take too long.
(leading the way toward  the partition) This way, ladies.
bar. Dave has just fitted a cylindrical record of "She Wa Only a Bird in a Gilded Cage" to an old-type phonograph.
Yep -- this is my last trip.
Why?
Old Harolday won't take back what he  said.
What'd he say?
"You're fired."
They both yell with laughter and slap one another on the  back.

from fireplace. Rocklin is standing in f.g. looking down the fire and making the inevitable cigarette from his poc dip. Seated at the table are Clara and Miss Martin. From  o.s. comes the sound of Zeke and Dave singing to the  phonograph record. Miss Martin glares indignantly in the  direction of the bar, obviously about to make a protest. this moment Stan comes from the kitchen with a large dish his hand which he dumps on the table.
There you are, folks. Dig in and  help y'rselves.
Miss Martin, sitting forward eagerly, suddenly sees the d of meat and freezes.
dish of meat. It is swimming in greasy brown gravy.
Miss Martin as she shudders dyspeptically and closes her  eyes.
bar, as Stan comes from the table to Dave and Zeke.
Supper, Dave?
(noisily) I'm drinkin' mine. Set 'em up.
table. Clara has filled a plate with food, which she offe to her aunt.
Auntie --
With my dyspepsia? Do you want to  kill me?
Clara hesitates for a second, then looks across to Rockli
Aren't you going to have any supper?
Reckon so.
He comes to table and begins to help himself. There is a  loud burst of laughter from the bar.
Young man, that driver's had all the  liquor he can take.
Has he?
You know he has. You're not a complete  fool, are you?
Frequently.
(to Clara, furiously) The rudeness of people in these parts  is appalling!
Clara looks apologetically at Rocklin, then away again  nervously. Suddenly, she sees something o.s. and drops he knife and fork with a little start.

window. A thin, unpleasant-looking face is seen through t glass. The windowpane is defective and so distorts the lo part of the face into a hideous smile. It is the younger the two men who were watching the coach outside the hotel
on kitchen door as Stan comes through with a dish of pota A man's voice is heard o.s. and he pulls up abruptly.
Well, well -- smells like a mighty  nice bit of veal.

CAMERA HAS PANNED TO include the side door next to the wi and almost opposite to the dining table. The owner of the face at the window (Bob Clews) is now standing in the doo Behind him is the man with the sheriff's badge on his dir vest (Jackson). As they come forward toward Stan, the lat shows obvious signs of nervousness.
Doin' yourself well these days, Stan.
A friend of mine was by an' sold me  a quarter of beef.
(insinuatingly) The same friend as sold you that  hide Bob, here, found stashed in  your barn yesterday?
Hide -- What hide?
The one that might send you to the  penitentiary.
(smugly) What did you do with it, Stan?
I never had no hide stashed --
(harshly) I saw it yesterday under the hay.
Then it must still be there.
No it ain't -- we looked -- Where is  it?
I tell ya --
(who has been an  interested witness) What is all this?
Jackson, as though noticing the women for the first time, raises his hat.
Afternoon ma'am. Miz Caldwell ain't  it?
No -- Martin -- Miss Martin -- This  is Miss Caldwell.
(to Clara) Glad to know you, miss -- Been  expectin' you at Santa Inez. I'm  Sheriff Jackson. Any relation of Red  Caldwell's a friend of mine.
(that oily smile) You're sure gonna brighten things up  considerable around the K.C. Ranch.
Miss Martin gives Clews an icy stare and snaps her eyes t Jackson.
(indicating Stan) What's going on with him?
Just a little matter of the law.
(hastily) Rustlin'.
Wrestling?
Rustlin' -- cattle stealin'.
Oh -- a thief --
(visibly worried) I tell ya I never --
(quickly) Save it --
(to Miss Martin) Matter of fact -- Bob, here, says  that the hide he saw yesterday had  the K.C. brand on it.
Oh -- hmmm -- well, what do you intend  doing about it?
(looking at Stan) Law's pretty harsh 'round here on  cattle thieves.
(being the kind man) Course, we don't want to make a  mistake with an old-timer, but --
Rocklin speaks from where he leans against the wall, casu smoking.
How about the owner of that beef --  mightn't he have somethin' to say  about it?
There's a pause in which all have turned their attention Rocklin.
Meanin'?
Red Caldwell -- he's the owner of  the K.C., ain't he?
(after a short chuckle) You're 'way behind the herd, mister --  Red Caldwell died three weeks ago.
(glaring at Clews) Was murdered, you mean.
That's right -- shot in the back --  not far from here.
(significantly to  Stan) Maybe he was gettin' on to things  about the cattle that's been missin'  from the K.C. lately.
I tell ya I ain't never had any hide --
(quickly) Well, you got beef --
(meekly defiant) Yes -- an' I got a bill of sale fer  it, too.
Jackson and Clews exchange a quick glance.
S'pose you let me see that bill of  sale.
(starts for kitchen) It's right out here.
Jackson follows, looking at the women.
Like I said -- I wouldn't want to  make a mistake with an ole-timer.
Jackson follows Stan into the kitchen. Clews moves to the fire and lunges there picking his teeth and eyeing Clara, who stirs uneasily under the man's gaze.

as Rocklin comes out of the thoughtful mood in which he h been plunged by the information about Red Caldwell and no the by-play between Clews and Clara. He frowns and makes movement as if about to rise. At the same time, Dave and  Zeke, whose voices have been heard throughout In the b.g. stagger into the shot.
(chuckling and pointing  to Miss Martin) See that one? (confidentially) She ain't got no laigs.
Hold your tongue. (to Zeke, who is gaping  at her) And you -- stop staring as if we  were monsters.
Zeke takes it and staggers into the b.g. near Bob Clews.
(to Rocklin) Where's Stan? We got to have another  drink.
He's outside tryin' to explain away  a hide.
Eh?
(indicating food) Seems we're eatin' stolen beef.
Somebody's loco. Stan might have  given house-room to bit o' dead beef,  but he'd never be fool enough to  leave the hide lyin' around. (to Zeke) How 'bout it, Zeke?
Zeke opens his mouth to speak, and slowly folds up, slidi down the wall to the floor.
as Clews comes from the fireplace and joins the group.
That's the way it is, Dave.
Dave has gone to Zeke's aid and now peers at Clews closel recognizing him for the first time.
(disgustedly) Oh -- it's you.
That's right -- your old pal Bob  Clews.
(shoves Clews) Git away from me -- you two-timin'  horse thief.
(grinning) Them's fightin' words, pardner.
Stan and Jackson come from the kitchen. Dave is again pic up Zeke, but seeing Stan, lets Zeke drop.
(moving to Stan) Hey, Stan -- don't let 'em hang  nothin' on you, you ain't done.  They're just a couple of fourflushers --  the pair of 'em, everybody knows  that.
Jackson addresses everyone present with an indulgent Smil
Crazy drunk.
(wheels on Jackson) Mebbe I am drunk -- mebbe that's why  I'm tellin' the truth -- I'm drunk  an' I'll say what I think -- I'll  say what I know.
Zeke, on the floor, takes up Dave's belligerent mood for flash.
So will -- I -- (goes out again)
Jackson goes to Dave.
Don't act up this ways, Dave -- They's  women watchin'.
Clews moves in to Jackson and Dave, and now both men urge Dave toward the door.
(attempting to throw  them off) Git your hands off me --
(to company in general) What he needs is a short lay-down.
(taking a step forward) I'll lend a hand.
(brushing past him) Me an' Bob'll look after him. We're  his friends -- come on, Bob. (as they steer Dave  through door) Careful now -- don't hurt him.
They exit. Rocklin stands frowning a second, then turns t the table where Stan is making a show of clearing dishes, etc.
(quietly to Stan) How are things standin' now between  you an' the law? (indicates direction  Jackson went out)
(not wanting to talk  about it particularly) All right, I reckon -- (looks at Rocklin;  more confidently) I guess this bill of sale -- (indicates it in Vest  pocket) -- kinda winded him.
Rocklin's lips curl in a wise smile.
Good thing you saved it.
Zeke is discovered on all fours crawling around on the fl near the table where the women sit. He seems to be lookin for something.
(mystified) What are you doing?
Zeke turns his hairy face up toward Miss Martin.
Musta been dreamin' -- Thought I was  sittin' on a pot of gold.
(wearily) There ain't no gold here.
(takes it) There ain't even a pot.
The door leading from the barn opens and Jackson enters  followed by Clews a few steps behind.
How is he?
Went to sleep soon's we laid him  down. (pulling off hat again) Sorry to have a ruckus in front of  you ladies. Dave's an ornery old  cuss when he gets goin' -- No shape  to drive on, I'm afraid.
(this is a fine kettle  of fish) Hmmm --
Don't worry, ma'am. Bob, here, 'll  take you on in -- knows every inch  of the road -- Don't you?
(grins) You bet.
Rocklin has been listening intently.
I'm drivin'.
of the group, with Clews looking significantly at Jackson who is obviously checkmated by Rocklin's remark.
(finally speaks) But if anything was to happen to the  ladies, I'd feel -- to blame.
Don't.
He turns abruptly and walks out the front door to the coa Jackson stares after him a moment, uncertain. Now he turn to the women.
You ladies want he should drive?
Miss Martin hesitates.
I'll be more'n glad to accommodate  you -- (smiles at Clara)
(resenting Clews'  familiarity) He's going with us anyway -- he may  as well drive.
Anything you say, ma'am.
MED. SHOT -- coach as Rocklin moves toward it from the ho A crudely made arrow shoots in and hits Rocklin lightly. warning hiss is heard o.s. and he turns quickly in the  direction of the sound.
MED. SHOT -- door of stable. The little Mexican who atten the horses is peering out from the stable.
(in a whisper) Venga con migo, senor.
The kid disappears inside the stable. Rocklin comes into  shot from the direction of the coach and enters the stabl

Rocklin comes through the door and moves toward the boy, is standing looking downward into some hay. CAMERA PANS DOWN to show Dave unconscious, with a nasty c in his scalp. Rocklin kneels into the shot. Over the scen comes the sound of retreating hoofbeats.
LONG SHOT -- from Rocklin's ANGLE in the stable, of Jacks and Bob Clews riding away. INT. STABLE - STAN'S PLACE - LATE AFTERNOON SHOT.
(to boy) Did they do it?
(nods) Si, senor. They hit him with a  pistola.
(matters) His friends, eh?
He kneels again, picks Dave up, and prepares to carry him out.
LONG SHOT of stagecoach traveling.
Rocklin on the driver's seat, handling the reins expertly

PANNING SHOT -- with Miss Martin and Clara now seated nex to one another. Clara is half asleep with her head agains the side of the coach. Miss Martin is sitting bolt uprigh but her eyes are closed and her head nods. CAMERA PANS to include the other side of the coach where Dave is sprawle in the seat, his head on a cushion, his mouth open, sound asleep. Suddenly he snores violently, and Miss Martin wak with a start and glares at him angrily.
PANNING SHOT on sign on window which reads: RED ROCK STAGE SANTA INEZ DEPOT Proprietor -- J. Harolday
CAMERA PANS to show the coach pulled up outside, with Roc lifting his saddle from the top of the coach, whilst a  stableman holds up Dave.
What happened?
Bumped his head.
(skeptically) Where -- on Iron Mountain?
Where's the best chance of a cheap  room?
(pointing) There's Cap's place across the Street --  the Sun-Up Saloon.
(with valise, indicates  saddle) I'll pick that up later.
group, to include the window of the coach. Miss Martin's  head appears.
(to stableman) This isn't the hotel.
No'm, lady. Hotel's up the street a  piece.
Are we expected to carry our bags at  this time of night?
(to Rocklin) Want to drive 'em on up?
(flatly) Nope. (offering a shoulder  to Dave) Here -- catch aholt.
The two move out of shot across the road, followed by the indignant gaze of Miss Martin.
PANNING SHOT -- opening on the sign over the door, which  reads:
CAMERA PANS to show Rocklin and Dave coming along the  boardwalk in front of the saloon. CAMERA PANS them to the swing-doors, which Rocklin pushes open, passing through i the saloon.

PANNING SHOT -- SHOOTING FROM BEHIND the bar toward the s doors as Dave and Rocklin enter. The bartender (Cap), a l tallish man of about 50, studies them as they enter, then turns and calls across the room.
Hey Doc!

CAMERA PANS to show a group of poker players seated aroun table. This consists of a well-dressed, powerful-looking of about 45 (Judge Garvey), with a smooth face and an  impressive manner; a flashily-dressed young man with a we face (Clint Harolday); a tough-looking cowboy of about 35 (Ab Jenkins); a pleasant-faced storekeeper of about 50 (P Fossler); and a little man with a weather-beaten face and intensely blue eyes (Doc Riding). Watching the game are S Haynes and Shorty Davis, the former a townsman and the la a cowboy. As they all look toward the door, Cap's voice  continues.
Customer --
Doc Riding looks quickly toward the door, taking in the  situation.
(to Haynes) Take my hand, Sammy.
Rocklin and Dave come to the bar. At the same time, Doc R comes into shot from the poker table.
What happened?
Bumped his head.
(dryly) I see. (examining the head) Looks like he's going to need a couple  or so stitches. (to Cap) Better get him upstairs.
The bartender looks dubious.
(nodding) Okay. You can book me a room, too.
As Rocklin and Doc Riding begin to lead Dave toward the  Stairs.
TRUCKING SHOT -- starting on big head of Dave, as he lies bed, with his eyes closed. His head is swathed in a clean bandage. He stirs and gives a little chuckle.
(muttering) No laigs.

CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Doc Riding at the bed and Rockl beyond, standing in the connecting doorway between two  bedrooms. The latter has a face towel in his hands and ha evidently been washing up. As Dave settles down comfortab in the bed, Doc Riding closes his bag, nods to Rocklin an moves toward the second bedroom.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- as Doc Riding comes through the doorwa from Dave's room.
He'll be all right in the morning.
Rocklin closes door behind him.
How about a snort?
Don't mind if I do.

He moves across the room, followed by Rocklin, who throws the towel down on the bed as he passes. For a second, he  hesitates as if about to pick up the gun-belt which is ly on the bed. Then, deciding to leave it, he follows the do through the door.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- at bar, with Cap Setting up glasses fo Doc Riding and Rocklin. He nods to indicate the bedroom  upstairs.
(with a grin) Will he make it?
Sure he'll make it. Can't kill off a  salty old hairpin like Dave that  easy.
You're right. Reckon Saint Peter  must be gitten' mighty tired of  dustin' off that doormat for him. (to Rocklin) By the way, how did you say it  happened?
(stolidly) I didn't.

(with a slight nod of  approval) That's right; you didn't. (casually) Reason I ask is, a couple fellers  was in saying how Dave was kickin'  up a ruckus up at Stan's place. (to Doc Riding) Sheriff Jackson it was and one of  the Clewses.
(with a look of  distaste) Oh!
Cap reverts to Rocklin, still casually, but with an under of friendly warning.
Tough customers, the Clewses.
Yeah -- don't pay to start something  with 'em you don't intend to finish.

(to Doc Riding before  Rocklin can answer) By the way, Doc, they tell me  George'll be out again. (to Rocklin, with the  same casual air) That's Bob Clews' brother. Jest done  a stretch in pen 'tentiary for horse  stealin'.
They string 'em up for that where I  come from.
(muttering into his  drink) Pity they didn't string him up while  they wore about it.
That's what Arly Harolday was sayin'  only this mornin'. (to Rocklin) You ain't met our Arly yet, I reckon?
He will, if he stays here long enough. (chuckles)
Hell-fire in skirts.
(raises his glass;  grinning) Well, here's now.
They down the drinks. There is a burst of excited comment from o.s. and they all look around toward the poker table
Poker table from bar. The flashily-dressed youngster is r in the stakes triumphantly.
What did I tell you? They gotta be  big to beat me!
Group at bar.
Clint Harolday's in luck tonight.
They're certainly running for him.  About time, too. He's taken a beating  this last week would shake a better  man.
Poker table and including bar. Sammy Haynes has risen and pushing back his chair.
Include me out.
Aw -- come on. Can't you take it?
Not that sort o' luck, I can't.  Besides, I on'y came in to oblige.
(turning to bar and  shouting) Come on, Doc. I still got to take  something from you.
(shaking his head) No more tonight, son. I've a full  day ahead.
Judge Garvey in foreground has been watching Rocklin, as trying to sum him up. He now leans forward with an  ingratiating smile.
How about you, sir? Care to sit In?  I'm warnin' you, though -- our young  friend here has been holding  phenomenal cards.
Rocklin smiles and begins to shake his head.
(with a cocky grin) Have a heart, Judge. This ain't no  two-bit saddle-tramp's game. This is  for real money.

Rocklin turns very slowly and stares at Clint. The others watch curiously. Without taking his eyes off Clint, he co forward slowly and stands looking down at him. Then,  unbuttoning the flap of his pocket, he takes out the wad bills and drops it on the table, at the same time sinking into the chair vacated by Sammy. The tension amongst the  onlookers relaxes and Clint grins at Garvey and winks  significantly.
Fine! Oh -- this is Pap Fossler;  Shorty Davis; Ab Jenkins; Mr.  Harolday, and my name's Garvey --  Judge Garvey. I didn't get your name.
I didn't give it. (to Pap, who is holding  the cards) Deal.

MED. SHOT -- poker table, including Cap, who is watching. Pap Fossler is dealing. There is an atmosphere of tension around the table, and it is obvious that Clint has been  losing. As he picks up his cards, he is unable to restrai smile of triumph. Rocklin makes a bet. Pap Fossler and th man next to him fold immediately.
Raise you twenty.
This is more than Rocklin has in front of him.
(quietly) Table stakes, Clint.
Not if he wants to dig.
He stares challengingly at Rocklin. Rocklin takes out a  wallet, from which he removes a bill and sees the raise.
(folding) No place for me.
Cards?
One.
(eagerly) One for me.
He reaches for it almost before it is dealt and as a resu the card, a Queen, falls face up. Clint looks at it gleef snatches it up and puts it in his hand. Rocklin watches h impassively.
Don't you know that Queen is dead?
I can take it if I want it.
Sure -- if you want -- but you'll  have to beat my hand with four cards.
(hotly) I'm playing these, mister!
Rocklin glances inquiringly at the other players. All are dead-panned, unwilling to interfere. Rocklin looks toward Cap, who stands near him.
(shaking his head) I'm not settin' in.
(smoothly) Why don't you split the pot?
I'm not splitting -- I'm betting!
He shoves all the money in front of him into the pot.
Are you calling?
(calmly) No.
Clint excitedly starts to rake in the pot.
I'm raising.
He shoves in the money in front of him, which is more tha Clint's and in addition takes from his wallet more bills.
Dig.
Clint, very excited, empties his pockets, which is not en
(to other players) Let me have some money
(speaking for all) You're in deep enough, Clint.
(disgusted, to Rocklin) I've called for all I've got. (spreads out his cards) Full house.
No good. (spreads his hand) Kings up. Your third queen is dead.
Rocklin starts raking in the pot. Clint, almost hysterica jumps up, draws his gun and thrusts it almost into Rockli face. The other players roll away from the line of fire.
(screaming) You -- mister -- get away from that  table. And get out of here. Maybe  from now on you'll know a full house  beats two pairs -- four-flusher!
Rocklin, his hands outspread, slowly straightens up, rise and backs away. At the foot of the stairs, he turns  deliberately and walks upstairs. When he disappears from  view --
Clint breaks the tension, looking from one to the other.
No man can run a bluff on me.
There is a cold silence.
(finally) He wasn't armed.
I don't like to tell men how to play  cards unless I'm settin' in -- but I  mebbe ought to have spoken up. (directly to Clint) That Queen was dead, Clint -- and  you know it.
(arrogantly) When anybody plays poker with me,  they play my game or not at all.
You can't just go makin' your own  rules, Clint -- (starts for the bar --  stops and turns) -- an' if I was you I'd hightail  outa here before he comes back.
(jolted) Comes back?
(wearily) He's the kind.
Cap turns and resumes his trek to the bar. Suddenly he st before reaching it and is looking up, o.s.
Rocklin is standing there grimly surveying the situation. he starts down the stairs...

head_text.subj: THE GROUP AROUND THE POKER TABLE

text: They are staring o.s. Clint is very uneasy. And now Rockl moves slowly into the scene.
(with deadly calm) I've come for my money.
(nervously pleasant) It's all yours, mister -- Cap, there --  Cap is an old gambler -- he says you  were right all the time.

Clint again looks around for approval, but gets no respon Rocklin comes slowly forward, picks up the money from the table and turns back to the stairs. As he reaches the foo of the stairs, he turns and looks straight at Garvey with peculiar expression.
By the way, Judge -- the name is  Rocklin.
TRUCKING SHOT -- on a small cracked mirror in which can b seen the reflection of a man shaving. A voice is heard  singing, atrociously off key.
She was only a bird in a gilded  cage... (etc.)

CAMERA PULLS BACK to show that the owner of tie voice is  Rocklin, who has almost finished shaving. As he scrapes h chin and whistles, peering at himself in the little crack mirror, he hears the sound of the door opening and turns, then ducks quickly as a boot flies past him, just missing the mirror. There is the sound of the door slamming and  Rocklin grins. He picks up the boot and goes to the door  leading to Dave's room.
As Rocklin enters, Dave is discovered almost dressed sitt on the bed. Rocklin, glad to see him, smiles and tosses t boot to him.
How you feelin'?
After that singin'? -- Thirsty. (pulls on his boot)
How's your head?
(evidently not aware  of what happened) Oh -- a mite hungover -- but I'll  feel better once I git downstairs.
He hurries out the hall door. Rocklin, amused at the old  coot, starts back into his room.

Rocklin is just coming through the door and sees somethin o.s., stops and freezes. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Bob Clews leaning against th open ball door leading into Rocklin's room. He smiles as  Rocklin sees him.
I knocked, but guess you didn't hear  me.
(closing door to Dave's  room) What do you want?
(grinning) Looks like you stirred things up  around here last night, stranger.
That all you came to say?
No. I got a message for you. (getting no response) From Old Man Harolday. Wants to see  you out front.
What about?
Maybe he wants to thank you for  teaching that pup of his a lesson.
(after a second) I'll be down.

Clews hesitates for a second as if anxious to wake sure h is coming, then, turning, he disappears into the hall. Ro wipes the last of the lather off his chin, buckles on his gun-belt and picking up his hat goes out, closing the doo

MED. SHOT -- Dave, at the bar, grabbing a bottle, pours  himself a drink which he sinks in one draught. He shudder and repeats the dose. During this, an excited murmur of v has been heard o.s. Dave turns and looks toward the far s of the saloon and suddenly gapes.

with Dave in f.g., and SHOOTING TOWARD the street. A grou of men, including Cap, the bartender, is gathered round t window looking out into the street. Dave staggers across them and begins to push his way to the window.
group at window as Dave pushes them aside to get a view o what is happening outside.
What's goin' on here?
Arly Harolday's on the warpath.

PANNING SHOT -- including Arly and Juan mounted in front the stagecoach office, which is situated diagonally acros the street from the Sun-Up. CAMERA HOLDS ON one group standing in front of Pap Fossle store, opposite the Sun-Up.
Here he comes. Watch the fun. This  should be good. Etc.
ON the window. The men inside, including Dave and Cap, ar pressed against the glass. CAMERA MOVES BACK and PANS TO the alleyway at the side of the saloon. Rocklin is coming toward the street.
Rocklin, as he comes out of the shadow of the alleyway an stands blinking in the full sunlight. Sensing something  unusual, he looks quickly around.

from Rocklin's ANGLE. CAMERA PANS OVER the groups in the  street, STOPPING ON one which includes Bob Clews. As Clew sees Rocklin, he nudges a bystander and looks toward the  stagecoach office with a grin. CAMERA PANS to include Arly and Juan.

Rocklin as he takes in the situation. With a grim look, h begins to move along the sidewalk, CAMERA TRUCKING WITH h Suddenly, there is the clatter of a horse's hooves and Ar gallops into shot, forcing the mare up onto the sidewalk barring Rocklin's progress.
(imperiously) Is your name Rocklin?
(coldly) Yes.
(contemptuously) I want that money you took from my  brother last night.
(quietly) Are you crazy? Or just ignorant?
(flaming) You took it at the point of a gun -- (suddenly whipping a  revolver from her  saddle holster) -- and I'm taking it back the same  way!
of group at window of Sun-Up Saloon.
of group including Bob Clews, as Clint Harolday rides in stares o.s.
Rocklin, as he looks coldly from Arly to the run and back again. Calmly taking the reins, he forces the mare's head and moves on. Furiously, Arly spurs the mare alongside, C TRUCKING WITH them.
(furiously) Stop! You! stop, or I'll kill you!
Arly and Rocklin. Rocklin continues along the sidewalk.
(pulls up her horse) Turn around.
Arly. She raises her gun.
A shot comes from o.s. and strikes the building close to  him. He stiffens but keeps on walking. Another shot comes even closer this time. He keeps walking.

head_text.subj: ROCKLIN HAS REACHED THE SWINGING DOORS OF THE SUN-UP

text: As he puts out his hand to push open the door,
Rocklin's hand on the door as four shots in quick success spatter a line down the door close to his hand.

TRUCKING SHOT -- Rocklin, as he continues his forward mov through the swing-doors. CAMERA PULLS BACK in front of hi into the saloon until it reaches the bar. Cap moves from  window with crowd and goes behind bar.
Whiskey!
CLOSE SHOT -- Arley with the smoking gun still in her han She stares wildly after Rocklin for a second, then wheels her horse violently toward the group which includes Cling Harolday and Bob Clews.
group surrounding Clews and Clint Harolday. The clatter o hoofs is heard and Arly gallops furiously into shot.
What happened?
You lied to me, didn't you?
Don't think I'll forget this. Making  a fool of me in front of the whole  town.
Before Clint can reply, she wheels the mare and gallops o of shot.
MED. SHOT -- as the customers, with Dave in f.g., mill ar Rocklin.
Boy, oh boy, was that a near thing!  She'd just as soon have hit you as  missed. You don't know how lucky you  were, son.
Don't I? (indicating whiskey  with a sickly grin) Why d'you think I need this?

He sinks the whiskey and begins to pour himself another. the same time, the swing-doors open and Bob Clews comes  through. AS Rocklin raises the glass to his lips, Bob Cle hits him on the back, causing him to spill the whisky.
Funniest sight I ever seen.
There is a moment's pause. Then with a slow, grim smile o satisfaction, Rocklin turns and knocks Bob Clews off his  feet.

with Bob Clews on the floor, tugging at his gun. As it co free of the holster, Rocklin brings his heel down on Clew wrist, grinding on it with his whole weights. Then, kicki the gun out of reach, Rocklin steps back. Bob Clews sits clutching his wrist and weaving back and forth.
(moaning) You broke it! You broke it!
Try another trick like that on me  and it'll be worse.
I never played you no trick. You  broke my wrist.
to include the bystanders. They look at Bob Clews without sympathy. He gets to his feet and stumbles back, collapsi in a chair.
at bar, Dave has taken the bottle from Cap and is refilli Rocklin's and his own glass ecstatically.
(gurgling with delight) Oh boy -- has somebody come to town!
He sinks both drinks quickly and is about to refill them  when Cap takes the bottle from him.
(to Cap) Where'll I find Judge Garvey?
He rooms behind his office down the  street. Don't usually pull up the  blinds till around noon, though.
(putting down money) He will this morning. (to Dave) See you later, old-timer...
As he moves toward the door.

Clint Harolday is seen at the window peering furtively to the Sun-Up Saloon. He suddenly notices something o.s. whi prompts him to say something which we of course cannot he Now Garvey appears at the window.
Rocklin, FROM Garvey's ANGLE as he leaves the Sun-Up and  starts toward the Judge's office.
Garvey and Clint, at the window. From their expressions i is apparent that anxious words are passing between them, now Clint suddenly drops from sight.
ON Arly and Juan, mounted. They see Rocklin going into  Garvey's place.
MED. SHOT -- TOWARD door, with Garvey at desk in f.g. The door opens and Rocklin enters.
(effusively) Oh, come in, Mr. Rocklin. Come right  in.
Rocklin looks him over for a second, then comes quietly t the desk.
I understand you were Red Caldwell's  lawyer?
(immediately on guard) I was.
Know anything about this?

He takes out a letter and hands it to Garvey. The latter  takes it slowly, handling it as if it were dangerous. He  looks from the letter to Rocklin and back again. Then  reluctantly, he opens it and begins to read. LETTER -- It reads: Dear Mr. Rocklin: Glad you have made up your mind to take the job. Enclosed find train fare and $150 advance on wages. Yours faithfully, J. Caldwell
Rocklin and Garvey. The latter looks up from the letter  completely bewildered.
I don't understand. Job? What job?
Foreman.
(gaping) On the "K.C."? (trying to take it in) But -- but why should he want you?
Why not? Good foremen don't grow on  bushes.
There is a little pause, with Garvey still bewildered.
(thinking hard) Is that your only motive for coming  here?
What other motive could I have?
I don't know -- It's just that Red  Caldwell was a peculiar man -- had a  funny way of doing things.
He studies Rocklin a short moment, then sits back comfort and relieved.
Well, I'm sorry, Mr. Rocklin, that  you've been brought all this way on  a fool's errand, but -- I'm afraid  the deal's off.
Off?
I don't want to be too hard on you,  but as executor of the estate I have  to consider the interests of the new  owner. How about, say, a hundred in  full settlement?
(thoughtfully) Well --
There is a knock on the door. Garvey rises and speaks on way to the door.
That's my last word -- think it over.
Garvey opens the door, and Miss Martin stalks in followed Clare.
(graciously) How do you do, ladies --
(icily) You are Judge Garvey, I presume.
(nods) Yes -- and you are --
Miss Martin -- and my niece, Clara  Caldwell.
(reaching for a chair) Of course -- of course --
Miss Martin sits stiffly as she eyes Rocklin coldly.
You came at a very opportune moment,  madam. This gentleman claims to have  some sort of a letter from the late  Mr. Caldwell, engaging him as foreman  of the "K.C."
What!
(to Garvey) What do you mean -- claims to have? --  You saw it, didn't you?

(before Garvey can  answer) You can't hold us to account for  every promise made by that man.  Everyone knows he wasn't responsible  for his actions half the time. And  if you think I'd have you as a foreman --
(finds it hard to  control himself) Listen, lady -- I'd rather walk for  somebody else, than ride for you.
(taken aback) Well -- the impudence --
All I come for this morning was to  pay beck the hundred and fifty Red  Caldwell sent in advance.
Oh, no
They all turn and stare at her.
Don't interfere, Clara. Of course he  must pay it back.
The railway fare -- well, I reckon  we can check that up against the  time lost and call it quits. (throws down a roll  of bills in front of  Garvey)
(summoning up her  courage) But, Mr. -- er -- I don't know your  name...
(raising his hat) Rocklin, miss.
Mr. Rocklin, it isn't fair for you  to pay anything back.
That's how I'd prefer it, If you  don't mind, miss -- never did care  fer owing favors to no one --  especially women.
(as if she had been  struck) Oh!
The sound of rapid steps approaching from outside is hear and they all look toward the door.
on door, as it opens to admit Arly. Ignoring everyone in room except Garvey, she comes abruptly to the desk, with riding quirt dangling from her wrist.
I've just heard they let George Clews  out of penitentiary and that he's  headed this way. You might tell him  from me, if he sets foot on the Santee  Ranch, I'll shoot him on sight.
But really, Miss Arly, why should  you deliver your message through me?
You have mutual friends.
If you're referring to Sheriff  Jackson...
I am.
But that's absurd. The fact that he  employs one of the Clews brothers  doesn't make the other his friend.
(contemptuously) Have it your own way; but it'd be  fair to warn him, because I mean it.
For the first time, she appears to be conscious of the  presence of the other women.

(hastening to change  the conversation) Oh, Miss Caldwell, this is Miss  Harolday -- Miss Martin, Miss  Caldwell's aunt. You should know one  another, seeing you'll be neighbors.  Miss Harolday runs the Santee Ranch  for her stepfather. She's a famous --  ah -- horsewoman in these parts.
(with ingenuous  enthusiasm) I know. I saw you ride into town  this morning. You looked lovely.  Just what I'd like to be.
Arly stares at her unbelievingly for a second.
(slowly, a bit  flustered) Yes?
She looks slowly from Clara to Rocklin, as if suspecting  collusion.
(completely innocent) Oh, this is Mr. Rocklin. He drove us  in from Garden City last night. He...
(dead pan) I already met Miss Harolday.
Oh.
(stonily, to Rocklin) I've a message for you -- from  Harolday.
(murmuring) What, again?
He wants you to come down to the  office.
What for?
He's got a proposition to make --  about riding for him. Sixty a month.
Hmmm -- That's a foreman's wages.

(suddenly exploding) I wouldn't offer you a red cent. (controlling herself) But it's his money. (bitingly) And the way things are shaping, maybe  we could do with somebody as mean as  you around the ranch.
(pushing her way  forward) I warn you, you're making a great  mistake. This man is no good.
Auntie!
(to Rocklin ignoring  Miss Martin) Well? D'you want the job?
Rocklin, as he stares at Arly with an enigmatic expressio Suddenly, he seems to make up his mind.
(indicating the door) Lead the way.

as Arly turns abruptly on her heel and exits the way she  came. Rocklin makes a little gesture to the ladies with h hat and follows. As he goes, Juan, who has been leaning  against the doorpost, follows, closing the door behind hi
(after they have gone) Auntie, why did you have to say that?  I simply don't understand you...
(cutting in, grimly) But I understand you. (scathingly) I'd be ashamed of myself. Throwing  myself at a man like that.
I... I... (suddenly bursting  into tears) Oh, you're horrid -- horrid. I wish  I'd never come.
She turns abruptly and drops onto the couch by the window CAMERA PANS TO HOLD A CLOSE TWO SHOT of Garvey and Miss  Martin.
You must excuse her. She's young.
And inexperienced.
Garvey leans back in his chair and smiles.
(significantly) And young people must be protected  from themselves at times -- don't  you agree?
Miss Martin throws him a quick look, which he returns  steadily.
(at last, with a grim  echo of a smile) Exactly.
Arly and Rocklin walking along the street, not far from  Harolday's office. Rocklin glances back toward Julio, who following a few paces behind them. He rides his horse and leading Arly's.
(to Arly, indicating  Julio) Does he always follow you?
(defiantly) He's not following me -- he's with  me -- he's always with me.
(takes it mildly) Oh -- just an old Indian friend.
(straight at him) The best friend I've got.
Rocklin nods, looks back again at Julio, then back to Arl as they go out of shot.
PAINING SHOT -- as Arly comes to from the street, followe by Julio and Rocklin.
(abruptly to Rocklin) Wait here.
CAMERA PANS her over to a door marked "PRIVATE," which sh opens without knocking.
MED. SHOT as Arly comes through from the outer office tow Harolday, who is seated at desk in f.g. At Arly's abrupt  entrance, he looks up, startled.
I've just hired a man named Rocklin  and said you made me do it. Sixty  dollars and he 'll earn it -- while  he lasts.
There is a little pause. Harolday's face is completely de pan. He looks out of the window for a second, then back a Arly.
(quietly) Why did you do it, Arly?
So I can fire him. I hate him. Clint  and he quarrelled last night. Clint  lied about it and I made a fool of  myself. (nodding toward the  outer office) He's outside now.
(with a little sigh) All right. Send him in.
Arly goes to the door and opens it.
(calling) Come in.
Rocklin comes in and Arly exits without a word, closing t door behind her.
as Rocklin comes from the doorway into f.g. of shot, faci Harolday, who is seated on the far side of the desk.
Mr. Rocklin, what happened between  you and my son last night?
Poker.
Hmmm. About this suggestion of you  working for me.
It's your suggestion, not mine.
Ye-es. Sixty dollars is big money.
(turning to go) If you've changed your mind...
No, no.... Wait a minute. I take it  you've had the experience.
Enough for Red Caldwell to hire me  as foreman.
Oh -- had Caldwell hired you?
Yeah -- but I won't ride for the new  owners -- so that leaves me open.
I see -- Were you a friend of Red's?
No -- I guess he just heard about  me.
A sudden clatter of feet is heard and all eyes turn towar the door.
as Dave, followed by Arly and Juan, bursts in. His eyes g around the room quickly until he finds Rocklin.
(as excited as a  schoolboy) George Clews is in town. He's seen  what you done to Bob and he's a- lookin' for you.
They all look quickly toward the window.
LONG SHOT -- from stagecoach office window. The center of the street is clear and men's heads are peering from door
MED. SHOT -- group at window, looking into street.
The street is clear.
Dave turns and looks curiously at Rocklin, who frowns  impatiently.
(to Dave irritably) Tell him I'll be out in the street  in front of the saloon.
(dashing out, radiant) Uh-huh!

The place is quite full and the atmosphere is one of  expectancy despite the outward casualness of the patrons. group lolls near the window, looking toward the stage off At the door a couple of customers peer out over the swing doors. The bar supports other customers engaged in variou private conversations but all are mindful of the presence George Clews who, with his brother, Bob, stands at the ba center, morosely toying with a glass of whisky in front o him. He is quite conscious of the subtle glances of the  others, but regards them all with disdain. He downs his d and speaks his thought to Bob.
I'm gonna get his ears.
Suddenly Old Dave appears in a high state of excitement, halts with the swinging doors half open.
(loudly) Hi you, George Clews --
George Clews turns.
Rocklin says if you don't come out,  he'll come in here after you, an'  tear you apart.

George Clews frowns. His eye catches sight of a king-size glass of beer being slid across the bar to Shorty Davis,  standing alongside him. That quick, Clews beats Shorty to the glass and hurls it at Dave, who ducks out. Cap,  anticipating trouble, brings a sawed-off shotgun up from  under the bar and now watches Clews and Shorty.
(taps Clews) That was my beer, you know.
(nastily) If he comes in again -- I'll throw  you.

Before Shorty can reply, Clews yanks his hat down over th little fellow's eyes, and gives him a backward shove that sends him sprawling into a corner where we leave him  struggling to get his hat off. The crowd resents this, bu doesn't dare do anything, except Cap, who holds his shotg in sight.
(to the Clews) That does it, boys -- you know where  the door is.
(to Bob) Com-mon -- I'll get his ears.
Not until I get my money --
George and Bob Clews are now a few steps from the bar. Th have turned as Cap spoke and are looking at the shotgun.
There's three drinks and a broken  beer glass.
(to Bob, after a  second's deliberation) Pay 'im.
George turns and starts for the doors as Bob comes back t the bar to settle up.
I'll get his ears.

head_text.subj: ON PAP FOSSLER AND THE OTHERS AT WINDOW

text: (quietly) That Rocklin'll kill him for sure.
Le's hope.
As George Clews steps outside, a mangy mongrel dog, baski close by, evidently recognizes him and tails it away, lea George blinking at him.
Rocklin -- FROM George's ANGLE. He is walking slowly forw down the middle of the street.
George, looking baffled by the steady approach.
(yelling) I'm coming -- and you'd better run!
He steps down from the sidewalk into the street and then  stands still again.
Rocklin -- CAMERA MOVING WITH him as he comes slowly and  steadily forward.
George. His hands are on his guns, but drunk or not, he h too much sense to draw too soon.
MED. SHOT -- Harolday watching from behind the window of office. Behind Harolday are Julio and Arly. The latter ma a step as if about to move to the door, but Julio restrai her.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- as Garvey, Miss Martin and Clara watch the scene below -- Garvey and Miss Martin excitedly and C in great distress.
CLOSER SHOT -- men in hotel doorway, taut with excitement
Rocklin -- SHOOTING PAST George, whose hands are on his g butts. Rocklin's thumbs are hooked in his belt as he cont slowly forward, his eyes fixed on George's.
(quietly) Draw a gun and I'll kill you.

George, as he stands bewildered and open- mouthed. Rockli enters scene, suddenly whips out his gun and brings it  crashing down alongside George's head. The barrel strikes though the crown of his hat and he goes down like a pole- axed steer.

MED. CLOSE SHOT -- group at window. Arly gives an involun exclamation of pleasure, which she instantly checks, then she moves abruptly out of shot, followed by Juan. Harolda continues to stare frowningly out of the window.
MED. CLOSE SHOT -- group at window, with Garvey obviously disapponted, Miss Martin bridling and Clara showing obvio relief.

MED. SHOT -- Rocklin and crowd as they swirl around him  offering congratulations. Dave pushes his way through the crowd and thumps Rocklin on the back in wild enthusiasm. the same time, the sound of a horse cantering is heard, a Jackson comes into shot.
(to Rocklin) Hey, you! What's this you been up  to?
I just laid a gun barrel over the  head of a drunk friend of yours --  same as you did over Dave's here  yesterday.
(surprised) Eh?
(blustering) I don't know what you're talking  about.
(calmly) You're a liar!
He turns contemptuously and begins to move back towards t stage office completely ignoring Jackson, who rides along blusteringly.
Now you lookee here, young feller.  You go on talking that way and you'll  find yourself in trouble.
The crowd which has been following now begins to razz him openly. He turns and glares, but without effect. He gives final shout to Rocklin.
Don't say you ain't been warned.
Pulling his horse around, he sets off in a lope up the st
as Miss Martin comes along the street, determinedly, foll by Clara, until she is face to face with Rocklin outside stage office where Arly and Juan are mounted ready to mov off.
(ignoring everyone  but Rocklin) I saw you. I saw you strike that  poor man.
Yes, ma'am. As hard as I could.
You ruffian, you!
Clara pulls her sleeve imploringly.
Let me go! (to Rocklin) I knew the sort you were the moment  I set eyes on you. You can't fool  me! You're nothing but a common  adventurer! Come, Clara!

She takes Clara by the arm and sweeps past them towards t hotel. Rocklin looks after them with a grim expression an then up at Arly, who has been listening intently. She ret his look steadily for a second. Then, with a mocking smil she wheels the mare and canters out of shot, followed by  Juan. He looks after her for a second; then with the same grim look, enters Harolday's office.
Harolday is standing at the window, looking toward the do having seen Rocklin approaching. The door opens and Rockl enters and resumes his conversation as though it were har interrupted.
-- Now what was that you were sayin'  about Caldwell?
You being hired by Red Caldwell only  confirms what I'd suspected -- he  was getting ready to fight.
(trying to get  information) Fight? Who?

Organized rustling. Well at least --  that's my belief. Red was no friend  of mine. Too fond of taking the law  into his own hands. But he had my  sympathy. He'd been harder hit than  any of us. And on top of it all, he  lost his foreman.
You mean, he quit on him?
He was shot -- in the back -- with a  bullet from the same caliber rifle  as got Red.
Got any ideas?
No -- Except that the man you just  pistol-whipped is in on it somewhere. (bitterly) Pity you didn't kill him when you  had the chance.
Rocklin realizes that maybe Harolday is trying to throw a curve -- trying to get him to talk.
Say -- it don't sound as if it's  goin' to be too easy for them wimmen  at the K.C.
(watching him keenly) Want to go back and work for them?
No, sir. And I ain't jumping at this  offer o' yours either because I don't  hold with working for wimmen.

(quickly) Oh, you mean my step-daughter. Well  don't worry. She won't interfere  with you...Rocklin -- I figure we've  been losin' cattle over a place called  Table Top -- it's the back way into  the Topaz Ranch and the perfect route  for rustlers -- I'm going to send  you up to the line camp -- you don't  mind working a lone hand -- do you?
(measuring) -- I like workin' that way.
(rising and holding  out a hand) Good -- be ready to move out this  afternoon.
On Dave and Pap Fossler engaged in conversation in front Pap's store. In the b.g. -- across the street, we carry t entrance to the Sun-Up Saloon.

(in his best sales  talk) -- now Pap -- I'm givin' you first  call on me services. They's lots of  other folks lookin' fer a good man,  too -- you know. So if you want me,  you better hurry and speak up because --
During Dave's speech Rocklin has come from the Sun-up car his valise. He pauses a moment, looking around. Dave sees him.
'scuse me, Pap -- Be right back to  find out when I start.
He hurries across the street toward Rocklin.
On Rocklin just stepping off the curb. Dave comes in to h
Whar you off to?
I'm riding for the Topaz Ranch.
They start across the street, slowly toward the stage off
What! -- Have you gone plumb loco?
Good money -- sixty a month
There ain't enough money in this  town to make it worth your while to  work for that gal.
Rocklin gives Dave a quizzical look, which Dave mistakes weakening.
When she gits goin' she can be  meaner'n a skillet full o' snakes.  She ain't goin' to forget the way  you made a fool of her today -- in  front of the whole town.
Hey, Dave.
Be right with you. (to Rocklin) It's pizen that's what it is -- jus'  plain --- What you want to hang around  this town for anyways? --
Dave and Rocklin have reached middle of the street. Pap  Fossler's voice comes again from o.s.
Hey, Dave.

Dave reacts with a squint in Pap's direction. He runs out toward Pap, but would rather stay with Rocklin. THE CAMER FOLLOWS Rocklin ACROSS the street To the stage office, wh see Arly and Tala sitting on their horses apparently wait for Rocklin. A third horse is standing by with Rocklin's  saddle on it. Rocklin, upon reaching the front of the stage office, pau a moment, to look over the horse carrying his saddle --  glances up to Arly.
Be right with you.
He goes into the stage of office, as we

LONG SHOT -- as Rocklin, Arly and Juan canter along a dir road over open country with the mountain ranges in the  distance. CAMERA PANS to show a buggy on the road ahead, approachin wooded dell where the road divides.

of the buggy, showing Miss Martin riding in front, beside Shorty Davis, who is driving, and Clara with her back to driver, facing the oncoming trio. Miss Martin hears the s of the approaching horses, and looks over her shoulder.
Arly, Juan and Rocklin, with Miss Martin in F.g. The latt scowls and looks quickly to her front as the riders draw  level with the buggy, Rocklin coining to the right, along Clara.
Good afternoon, Mr. Rocklin. (looking at the sky) Lovely day, isn't it?
Reckon it is pretty nice. So you're  moving in on the "K.C." eh?
(hesitating and  throwing a look toward  Miss Martin) We-el, not exactly moving in. You  see...
with Miss Martin in f.g. and SHOOTING OVER her shoulder t include Clara and Rocklin.
(acidly, locking  straight ahead) Do you have to discuss our private  affairs with every rag-tag-and-bobtail  cow-person we meet, Clara?
(in a low voice) Auntie!
Sorry if I butted in, ma'am. Jest  passing the time o'day.
We can do very well without it --  thank you. (with a look over her  shoulder) And you're keeping your lady friend  waiting.
Rocklin looks quickly in the same direction.
from Rocklin's ANGLE, with Arly and Juan at the fork in t road. They are looking back towards the buggy which has t the lower road to the right of the copse.
with Arly and Juan in f.g. and the buggy in the distance. Rocklin raises his hat to the women in the buggy and cant back to Arly, who has been watching with a peculiar  expression.
(coldly) I thought maybe you'd changed your  mind again.
(cheerfully) Nope.

She looks at him angrily for a second as if about to say  something sarcastic. Then, repressing herself, she wheels her horse and canters off along the side of the copse. Ro throws an amused glance, at Juan, who has been watching w an enigmatic expression. He returns Rocklin's look with a stern, menacing frown. Then, with a gentle flick of the r he urges his horse after Arly. Completely baffled, Rockli scratches his head for a second, then follows.
MED. SHOT -- as the three canter up the driveway to a sma looking ranch house. Arly dismounts and throws her reins Juan.
(over her shoulder to  Rocklin) Juan'll show you the bunkhouse. I'll  talk to you about your duties in the  morning.
Before Rocklin can speak, she runs quickly up the steps o the verandah and disappears into the house. Leading Arly' Horse, Juan moves out of shot to the left of the ranch ho and Rocklin follows.
MED. SHOT -- as Juan comes into shot leading the mare,  followed by Rocklin. They both dismount and begin to off- saddle.
How far is the line-camp at Table- Top?
Twenty-five -- thirty mile.
I'm moving out there first thing in  the morning. (as Juan turns and  stares) Boss' orders. Care to show me the  way?
There is a moment's pause. Then, what almost amounts to a smile of relief, crosses Juan's face.
I will show you.
LONG SHOT -- as Rocklin and Juan ride out from the ranch  through the early morning mist and turn off in the direct of the distant line of mountains.
LONG SHOT -- as the two leave the open country and enter mouth of a steep and narrow gorge at the foot of the moun range.
as Juan pulls up and dismounts, followed by Rocklin.
(pointing ahead) The trail is straight ahead. You  will find the cabin at the top. (turning back to his  horse) Adios, Senor.
(challenging, but  perfectly friendly) Senor Romerez, it appears that you  do not like me.

For a second Juan does not reply. Then, as he speaks, he  takes a tobacco pouch from his pocket. Rocklin, his mind other things, does not take particular notice of the pouc but we cannot help notice the pouch ornament -- a steer's head of hammered silver.
(during the above  business) Senor, that is true. I do not like  you.
Why?
(extending the pouch) Permit that I offer you a cigarette.
Rocklin shakes his head. Juan, having spilled tobacco in paper, now puts away the pouch and rolls his own.
It is not your fault that your shadow  is black. But you will only bring  unhappiness to my senorita. I do not  blame you, but I fear I must hate  you.
He turns abruptly and mounts the waiting horse; then look down from the saddle.
Adios, Senor.
He rides quickly out of the shot.
MED. SHOT -- as Rocklin forces his horse up the last few  feet of the steep trail at the top of the canyon, and pul up at the top of the rise with a look of amazement.

A rich meadow stretches ahead with a stream running throu it, and a cabin at the far end. Steep escarpments surroun the lush meadow land, making an idyllic scene. As Rocklin comes slowly into shot with the same look of startled  appreciation on his face and begins to move toward the ca

LONG SHOT -- of Juan, as he canters across open country t the ranch. CAMERA PANS to include the road from Santa Inez along whi approaches a smallish freight wagon, pulled by two horses As the driver sees Juan and waves his whip, the Mexican  swerves from his course and canters toward the wagon.
wagon, which we now see is being driven by Dave. On the s of the wagon is written: TRANSPORT & GENERAL FREIGHTAGE - Pap Fossler and Sons. Juan canters into shot and pulls up alongside the wagon.
Hiya there.
Buenos dias, Senor Dave. (looking at name on  wagon) You have found new employer, eh?

Yeah. Haulin' freight for ole Pap  Fossler. Got a letter here for that  crazy galoot, Rocklin. (with a little Wink) From the little Caldwell girl. Seems  mighty took up about sumpin'. Made  me promise to deliver it personal. (indicates letter)
But Senor Rocklin is not here.
Lordy -- he ain't quit already...
(shakes head) I have just accompany him to Table- Top.

Shelley, a Negro servant of the Harolday household, is  discovered sweeping the front porch. Behind him we see Cl open the door -- peer furtively out -- then cross the por to its edge when he looks o.s. as though searching for  someone. Shelley, meantime, has noticed Clint, but goes right on w his sweeping. His only reaction is a disparaging glance o his shoulder.
(turning to Shelley) Have you seen Arly?
No, suh, Ah didn't see Miss Arly  today, but Ah seed her las' night,  and she shore was mad.
To emphasize his point, Shelley puckers his mouth in a  whistle.
Plenty mad!

Clint's face tightens as he anticipates what is in store him. Over the scene comes the gradually increasing sound a feminine voice, gayly humming the notes of a popular tu of the period. Clint's strained features relax in a can-t be-Arly expression, while Shelley stops dead in the middl of a sweep, and now both stare incredulously, o.s.

From their ANGLE we first see only the corner of the hous while the owner of the voice approaches from the other si Now Arly comes into view, entirely oblivious of Clint and Shelley watching her. She seems more attractive, in a fem way, this morning. It may be the skirt and blouse she is  wearing. Then again it may be the flower she is, even now adjusting in her hair. The presence of the two men sudden startles her. The song ends abruptly, while her hands fal quickly away from the flower.
As Arly moves toward the porch, Shelley snaps back to lif and resumes sweeping -- but furiously. Clint regards the  girl in the vague manner of the puzzled gent he is.
(not too definitely) 'Mornin', Arly --
Arly is coming toward Clint.
(pleasantly) 'Mornin', Clint.
She steps close to Clint, and he slowly backs up a step, he does not know she came up to him merely to pick up her jacket lying on the ground near the step.
(as Arly leans down  to pick up the jacket) You must be feeling pretty good.
Arly straightens up with the jacket in her hand, and the  corner of her mouth curls in a faint smile. She turns now and starts along the walk, and takes only a few steps whe Clint comes to her side.
(as he joins Arly) Say, Arly -- about that poker game,  night before last, I ---
(tossing it off) Forget it.
(did he hear correctly) Forget it?
Arly pays no attention to Clint. She is looking o.s. and  stops walking.
Tala, on his horse, as seen by Arly. Over the scene comes Arly's voice calling from a distance.
(calling) Tala.
Tala reacts to the call by heading his horse at a slightl different angle.
Arly is looking o.s. toward Tala. Clint is now eyeing his sister up and down quite openly. She turns her head now a catches Clint looking her over.
(after a stilted pause) Well --
(with a perplexed  smile) What is this? --
A gesture of his hand indicates the way Arly has gotten  herself up. That quick, Arly's hand goes to the flower in her hair. And, that quick, she guiltily withdraws it.
(bravely nonchalant) What do you mean?
What do I mean? --
Before he can explain, Tala pulls up in his horse and we  hear his voice over the scene.
Good morning, Arliete.
Tala sitting astride his horse smiles down at the girl.
Good morning, Tala.
You have make yourself very pretty  today.

Arly is jolted by Tala's innocent remark, and she can't h giving Clint a little side glance in the way of reaction. Clint has not missed Tala's crack nor Arly's glance, and  when she gives it to him he says:
(pleasantly) See what I mean?
He tosses her an altogether knowing look now, and leaves, going up the walk toward the house. Arly turns to Tala.
Have my horse saddled and sent around  right away -- will you? (then as a casual  afterthought) You can have that Rocklin bring it.
She glances over her shoulder toward Clint going up the w And then, looking back to Tala, finds he hasn't moved, bu remains smiling down at her.
What's the matter?
(easily) Rocklin is not here.
(breathlessly) He quit?
He has gone to the line camp at Table  Top.
What?
It was Mr. Harolday's orders.
Arly looks away. Her eyes stare blankly into space as she struggles with the mixed emotions of anger and disappoint Tala, aware of her plight, slowly dismounts and comes to girl's side.
(in a fatherly manner) Why do you make your heart heavy  with thoughts of him, little one. --  He is not for you.
(bitterly) Be quiet.
He has made the choice, Arliete.  With your own eyes you saw it  yesterday.
(impatiently) Oh --
And she, too, has opened her heart  to him -- Already she has summoned  him to her.
(this turns her around) What do you mean?
Dave -- of the white beard -- carries  a letter to Rocklin -- It is from  her.
How do you know that?
I have just now met Dave, and he  tell me. -- So now he rides to Table  Top.
Arly is quiet a moment.
Little one you --
(quickly, as she starts  for the house) Oh, leave me alone.
entrance to ranch. Entering the driveway from the directi of Santa Inez, comes Harolday, still looking the distingu citizen.

head_text.subj: HAROLDAY RIDES UP TO THE PORCH

text: Good morning, Julio -- morning Arly. (to Julio as he  dismounts) Fetch my briefcase -- it's on my  desk.
Julio exits.

head_text.subj: HAROLDAY TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO ARLY WHO

text: still smarting under the disappointment about Rocklin, se lost in thought. After regarding her a moment Harolday sp
Looks like we're going to get that  land we've been wanting along the  river bottom.
Arly turns her eyes on Harolday, who continues.
I didn't tell you -- but I bought  the mortgage on the Hardman ranch,  and it's due today -- On my way over  there now.
Arly's eyes burn as she tosses her head slightly.
Did you send that Rocklin to Table- Top?
I did.

(furiously) Well, let's get things straight.  This place was my mother's -- now  it's mine and Clint's -- It's true  you've been helping out -- but the  way things are going we'll soon be  able to pay you back every penny we  owe. Meanwhile, I'm running this  outfit and I expect to give the  orders.
You generally do.
Why did you send Rocklin up to Table- Top?
It seemed to me a good idea -- what  with all this rustling going on --
Who'd ever try driving cattle over  Table-Top? -- Unless they were crazy.
(coldly) I don't agree with you. In any case --  if you must have it -- I'd no  intention of engaging a man at  foreman's wages just to gratify the  whims of a jealous woman!
(dangerously) You take care what you're saying.

(very controlled) It's you should take care, my dear.  I'm afraid there's one man you can't  rawhide into jumping the way you  want. You've made a fool of yourself  over him once. Better watch out you  don't do it again.
He turns abruptly and walks off the verandah.

as Harolday comes from the verandah to his horse. Juan is standing there with the briefcase which Harolday takes wi a yank, mounts his horse and rides out. The CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE on Arly, who stands in furious  silence watching Harolday ride away.

location: CANYON ROAD ON THE WAY TO TABLE-TOP

text: Old Dave is jogging along in his wagon. A rumble of thund echoes through the canyon. Dave reacts with a look toward the sky.
of storm clouds gathering.

A night shot of the mountain road near Table-Top. It is a wooded section of the plateau, and occasional flashes of  lightning illuminate the big trees skirting the road. Dav in his wagon, looms out of the b.g., and as he nears the  camera we hear him urging the team through the downpour. he passes and continues hurriedly on his way, we
CLOSE SHOT on a soiled and wrinkled envelope lying on a t It is addressed to: Mr. Rocklin c/o Santee Ranch

The CAMERA PULLS BACK and Rocklin is revealed at the tabl looking down at the letter. His hat is tipped back on his head, and his sleeves are rolled up. He is mixing dough i bowl sitting on the table near the letter, and his hands all gooey. Dave is discovered in front of the fireplace w his outer shirt and socks are drying. It is dark outside, but the storm has abated. Rocklin goes to a shelf near th fireplace to get a pan.
(during the above) Durn funny -- that storm quittin'  just about the time I get here.
No funnier than you sloggin' through  it, just to deliver a letter from a  woman.
(disgustedly) Reckon I'm gettin' to be more of a  fool the older I get.
Dave watches Rocklin at the table shaping the dough for  biscuits and putting it in the pan.
When are we gonna get around to  readin' it?
Rocklin cannot help smiling a bit at the way Dave include himself in.
Thought I'd wait till mornin' --  might be bad news an' I wouldn't be  able to sleep.

Dave screws up his face in utter disgust and turns his  attention to his drying clothes. Rocklin, meanwhile, takes a flour sack from the table, wi the dough from his hands and picks up the letter. He goes over to the fireplace, opening the letter the while, and  sits on the bench. Dave, seeing this, edges discreetly ar in back of Rocklin in order to see over his shoulder. The letter open, Rocklin takes out a roll of bills along  with the folded message. He lays the envelope on the benc
Mmmm -- dineroo.

Rocklin places the money in his shirt pocket for the mome and opens the folded message. LETTER. It begins with the usual Dear Mr. Rocklin. Rocklin's voice is heard over the insert as he reads from here.
(reading) Forgive me if this letter is a trifle  incoherent, but I am terribly worried  and unhappy.
Who wouldn't be -- livin' with that  ole screech owl.

(continues to read) I am desperately in need of help and  advice from someone whom I feel I  can trust, and I am appealing to  you, because I regard you in the  same way my Uncle surely must have.  I heartily dislike and distrust Judge  Garvey --
(interrupting) Huh -- Smart girl --
