(going on) But my Aunt seems to have suddenly  revised her opinion of him, and now  wants me to place all my affairs in  the Judge's hands and return east.  Such is certainly not my wish.
(significantly) Looks kinda like she's formed an  attachment.
Rocklin glares up to Dave.
(quickly) For the locality, I mean.
(continues reading) I wanted so much to give ranch life  a trial, but fear circumstances are  against me, especially in view of  the recent Indian trouble --
(explosively) Indian trouble -- (in normal tone) Good Lord, they ain't been any Indian  trouble around here in --
(caustically) You want to hear the rest of this?
(getting the inference) Might's well -- come this far.
(reading) I want to apologize for what took  place this afternoon. And I am  returning the 150, because I feel it  is rightfully yours. You must take  it. Faithfully yours, Clara Caldwell.

The letter finished, Rocklin regards it a moment, then sl returns it to the envelope as he gazes thoughtfully into fire. Dave meantime straightens up -- scratches his shaggy top, and turns his attention once more to his drying clothes.
(feeling his socks) Well -- what do you make of it?
Rocklin continues looking into the fire as he lays the le back on the bench and takes out tobacco to roll a cigaret
Somebody's sure bustin' to get her  out of there.
Dave sits alongside Rocklin and begins putting on his soc
Indian trouble --
(after a pause) Wonder why the old lady's playin'  along?
(sourly) Baaa -- Wimmen -- Who can ever figure  'em? (pause) Got to admit though, I feel a mite  sorry for the young'un -- nice little  tyke.
Too nice for this country.
(after a slight pause) She's shore a pretty thing.
Rocklin has been mulling things over.
Don't know how I could help her --  even if I wanted to -- I don't know  any thing about this Garvey -- or  Caldwell -- or --
Well, now -- I could mebbe help you  out some, there -- Fact, I could  tell you somethin' 'bout ole Red  that might be interestin'.
You must have known him pretty well --  What kind of a man was he?
Rocklin goes to the table and resumes molding biscuits. Dave has his boots on and is putting on his outer shirt.
Caldwell? -- The best -- cantankerous  cuss -- but a real cowman, believe  me -- He was a big feller, like  yourself -- Fact, you coulda passed  fer a blood relation, come to think  of it.
(casually, as he busies  himself with the  biscuits) Was the Judge and Red friends?

(anigmatically) That's what you'd say. Garvey managed  all Red's business. Besides which  they was regular drinkin' pals --  played poker together most nights --  tho' they do say Red got the worst  of it.
Red was a gambler, eh?
Oh, yeah -- reckon a pretty poor  one, tho' -- still you'd say him and  Garvey was friends.
(after a side glance  to Dave) Anything ever happen to make you  think they weren't?
(moves close to Rocklin) Rock -- I'm gonna tell you somethin'  I ain't never told anybody.
(with a slight smile) Think you can trust me?
Dave grimaces his confidence.
The last time I seen Red was the day  he died --
In the pause Rocklin remains silent.

-- 'Twas in town -- he jus' come out  of the stage office. Tried to book  passage to Garden City but couldn't  on account I had a full load. --  Well, sir, he took me aside and give  me a printed sheet of paper and says,  "Read it." I looked it over and fer  as I could see it was a paper from  one of them Chicago sportin' firms,  tellin' how to manipulate trick  playin' cards.
Marked cards.
(nods) Reckon so. -- Seems Red found some  cards and this paper in a coat one  of his friends loaned him one night.
Whose was it?

Well, now that's just what I asked --  but all he said, was that it belonged  to a good friend. Then he said he  wasn't waitin' fer the next coach,  but was ridin' over to see the  district judge about it alone.
That's when they got him.
Yes, sir -- 'bout a mile or so from  Stan's place. A bullet in the back  an' his pockets empty.
How come you never told this before?
Who was there to tell? -- Sheriff  Jackson? -- Him an' Garvey's thick  as thieves.
How about what's his name -- Harolday? --  He's no friend of the Judge's, is  he?
Hates his guts -- sure riles him to  see young Clint hangin' onto the  Judge's coattails. All the same, I  jus' decided to keep my mouth shut  and my eyes open.
(after a pause) Even if it was Garvey Red was talkin'  about -- it don't follow that he  killed him.
No -- general opinion is that it was  rustlers.
Why would rustlers take the evidence  Caldwell had with him?
Rocklin moves away to a large earthen jug holding water a Dave talks.
Looks to me if you get the man who  owned the marked cards, you get the  killer.
(drinking) Funny tho' -- first the K.C. foreman --  then Caldwell -- an' now these women.
Lordy -- you ain't thinkin' somebody  might try bumpin' them?
(slowly, to himself) I'm not so sure somebody hasn't tried  already -- (to Dave) Remember, when we stopped to change  horses on the way Over from Garden  City --
Shore -- you told me how Jackson and  Clews tried to frame Stan.
(nods) Yeah. Like they wanted to be sure  he'd keep his mouth shut about  something.
Dave sits down on a box sitting against the wall, directl under the large earthen jug of water.
And layin' that gun across my skull --  an' offerin' to drive the coach  themselves.
A dark, mysterious figure on a horse raises his rifle --
(nods) It was almost as if --

A shot splinters the windowpane and shatters the earthen on the shelf directly above Dave's head. The contents pou down on Dave and he topples over. Rocklin meanwhile has w the lantern off the table and ducked. They are both on th floor in the faint glow coming from the fireplace.
(going to Dave) You all right?
(blustering) Will be if I ever get dry.
Rocklin takes off his hat and puts his finger through two holes drilled by the bullet.
Lookit that --
Good Lord --
Rocklin puts the hat aside -- crawls over to his gun belt straps it on.
Come on --
He opens the door cautiously. Then sneaks out, followed b Dave.

Rocklin and Dave stand close to the cabin, just clear of door, tensely scanning the surrounding darkness. Water can be heard dripping from the cabin roof, and an o hoots in a near-by tree. The sound of neighing horses comes from the direction of corral. Both men re-act.
My team.
Almost immediately the neighing is repeated, but this tim from another direction entirely -- and from a distance.
That's not your team.
He moves to the corner of the cabin, followed by Dave.
and now it starts away, galloping through the deep grass the edge of the clearing. Only the lower part of the anim is seen, along with the legs of the rider.

head_text.subj: ROCKLIN AND DAVE HEAR THE SOUND OF RETREATING HOOF BEATS

text: And they can barely make out their quarry riding hell-ben toward the deep blackness of the trees. Rocklin fires and runs out into the moonlight in the clea Dave close behind. Rocklin halts -- fires again -- and again. Dave fires. The mysterious rider is now swallowed by the night. Dave starts after him again. Looking back, he sees Rockli has not moved.
Come on --
No use -- he's gone.
Mebbe we winged him.
He starts through the wet grass alone. Rocklin turns back toward the cabin.

He has reached the edge of the clearing where a slight  embankment leads to the level of the trees. He is just  starting up to higher ground when his eyes catch somethin on the embankment, shining in the moonlight. It proves to a tobacco pouch bearing a steer's head of hammered sliver It is dry, so has evidently just been dropped. Dave pocke it, and proceeds warily along the mystery rider's trail.
He looks back in Dave's direction, and then looking towar the cabin, suddenly stops and tenses.

head_text.subj: THE CABIN DOOR IS PARTLY OPEN

text: and through it Rocklin can plainly see an indistinct form moving in the faint glow of the dying fire.

head_text.subj: ROCKLIN DRAWS HIS GUN AND MOVES STEALTHILY TOWARDS THE CA

text: Rocklin has reached the entrance unheard, and silently wa the strange figure, its back to him, now headed for the  fireplace with his saddlebag, taken from the bunk. He see the intruder start emptying his saddlebag on the bench in the light of the fire. He sees him suddenly stop and pick something hidden from his view. At that instant, Rocklin slams the door shut. The intruder whirls around. It is Arly -- tense -- and now defiant. The two regard each other like vicious animals in the sam cage. Arly's heart is pounding, but you would never know And now Rocklin, his gun away, starts closing in, slowly but Arly holds her ground -- her eyes never leaving his. When Rocklin reaches Arly, he takes her one hand from beh her back, and slowly forcing it up sees what is obviously Clara's letter in her tightly clenched fist. He tries to  open her hand, and Arly, knowing she lacks the strength t prevent it, suddenly whips out a knife with her free hand But that quick, Rocklin grabs the knife hand, and without any apparent effort, wrenches it free of her grasp and to it across the room, where it lands on the bunk. Arly rela her grip on the letter meanwhile, and Rocklin gets it, an tears it very deliberately, letting the pieces fall at he feet. He turns his back on her now, going over to his hat on th floor. Arly is furious in her helplessness and humiliation. And  Rocklin's smug manner isn't helping any. He picks up his and, glancing at Arly, puts his finger once more through bullet holes.
(smiling wryly) Not bad shootin'.
(right back at him) You think I did that?
Sure -- to draw us away from here. (looks at his hat) You know, you cut it mighty close --  Good thing I ain't got brains enough  to fill it.
Rocklin puts his hat on. He sees Arly looking down at the torn letter.
(suppressing smile) Too bad you had to come 'way up here  through that storm for nothin'.
(affectedly) I haven't minded a bit -- (harshly) -- because I came up to fire you.
Oh -- (nods) I see.
Rocklin goes toward the bunk with his saddlebag.
Get out of here -- get off the Santee  and don't ever come back.
Mind if I wait for Dave? He ought to  be along any minute -- Be funny if  he winged that shadow of yours.
If you mean Juan -- you're loco.  He's not even up here.
(mildly surprised) You came up alone?
Yes.
(half believing her) Then who was that we took out after?
The man who shot at you.
Rocklin sits on the bunk and casually picks up Arly's kni
Who was he?
I don't know.
You mean you won't tell.
I mean I don't know -- Why should I  lie to you?

That last from Arly brings a kind of smile to Rocklin's f a smile that says in effect -- "Are you kidding?" He gets from the bunk to go to the door, and finding himself stil holding Arly's knife, throws it back to her in a seemingl casual manner. It passes too close to Arly for comfort an Rocklin just opening the door, gets the knife right back that close to his ear he feels the breeze. He looks at it quivering in the door. Then, moving to Arly in what could construed as a threatening manner, he takes her in his ar and kisses her. Arly is caught completely unaware. Rockli action disarms her. But it is, after all, what she really wants, so before the kiss ends, Arly's arms slowly entwin themselves around Rocklin's neck. In the middle of the ki Rocklin gently but forcefully takes her arms from around neck and puts her from him.
I guess you forgot -- you jes' fired  me.
He goes to the bunk -- picks up his saddlebag, coat, etc. and starts for the door. Arly has been silently watching.
(turning near the  open door) So long.
Dave's voice is heard just outside the cabin door.
Hey, Rock --
Dave now rushes through the door, puffing and excited.
-- He got away -- but guess what, I --
He sees Arly and pulls up abruptly.
(slowly to Dave) You guess --
Rocklin gives Arly a disparaging side glance and starts o
(to Dave, who is trying  to figure things out) Come on.
Rocklin is headed for the corral as Dave catches up to hi
(glancing back to the  cabin) Fer a man who's got a despise fer  wimmin, you sure do get all snaggled  up with 'em.

Arly, her back to us, is standing in the open doorway wat the two headed for the corral. Her mood is evidenced by the manner in which she suddenly slams shut the door. As she turns and leans against it, w see tears in her eyes, and hear suppressed sobs. Her eyes light on the bits of torn letter, and presently we see he face set itself grimly, and now she walks toward the fire and, passing the torn bite of paper, kicks at them viciou

LONG SHOT -- of Rocklin as he comes riding into town. As nears the corner where the stage and Harolday's office is situated, the CAMERA MOVES IN, getting Rocklin and one of the Harolday employees repairing the wooden sidewalk near the hitching rail.
(as he dismounts) You work for Harolday?
The man nods.
Here's one of his horses -- I'll  pick up my saddle later.
He enters the building.

PANNING SHOT on Harolday as he sits at the desk working o ledger. The sound of a door opening is heard. Harolday lo up casually as if expecting a customer, then suddenly gap CAMERA PANS to include doorway in which stands Rocklin.
Howdy...
(frowning) I thought I sent you up to Table- Top.
That's right.
(slowly) What happened?
(taking off his hat) Well, this, for one thing.
He pokes a finger through the hole in the crown. Harolday eyes narrow.
(after a little pause) I told you you'd regret letting that  rat Clews off so easy.
Rocklin looks at him with a queer expression without repl
What's the matter? Don't you think  it was him, then?

(slowly) I been figgerin'. Don't seem  reasonable Clews was in condition to  take that sort of chance alone...  Besides -- how could he have known I  was up there -- that soon. And --  George Clews ain't the only one I've  run contrariwise to in this town.  There's that Mexican, for instance.
Juan?
He as good as told me yesterday that  him and me was due for a run-in one  of those days. (suddenly nodding  toward window) And then there's him!
Harolday looks sharply toward the window.
MED. SHOT from office window. Clint is hurrying across fr the direction of the Sun-Up Saloon toward the office.
PANNING SHOT on Clint as he enters from street and crosse to the door of Harolday's office.
MED. SHOT on door of inner office with Harolday at desk i f.g. As the door opens it conceals Rocklin from Clint.
(excitedly) I just heard that -- that Rocklin  was -- (sees Rocklin)
(slowly) Was what?
(subdued) Was shot at last night.
(very calm) Mr. Rocklin was just telling me all  about it. (significantly) Any idea who might have done it?
Clint looks quickly at Harolday and back at Rocklin with  frightened eyes.
Not me.
Rocklin makes no reply.

You ain't trying to pin it on me? (his courage returning) 'Cause if you are, you're in for a  big disappointment. I was over at  the Sun-Up playing poker with the  Judge and the rest of the boys till  early morning. If you don't believe  me, ask for yourself.
(after a pause) All right. I believe you. But that  don't mean you couldn't tell a thing  or two as would help -- if you wanted.
(very nervous again) What d'you mean?
(sharply) Yes. What sort of thing would Clint  here know about, that would help  identify the man who tried to kill  you last night?
This for one.
He pulls out the tobacco pouch which Dave found at Table- Top.
Ever seen it before?
Clint as he stares wide-eyed at the pouch.
group, with Rocklin and Harolday both watching Clint inte
(harshly) Well, go on -- speak up. Did you  ever see it before?

(avoiding Harolday's  eye) No. Course I didn't (suddenly raging at  Rocklin) Quit riding me! I don't know nothin'  about it I tell you. Jest because I  had a run-in with you over a game o'  cards, that don't mean I'd sneak up  on you in the dark and...
Rocklin's disdainful smile takes the speech out of Clint, who just sort of runs out of words. Rocklin hesitates for second then moves toward the door.

Harolday and Clint are at window looking past camera towa the street. They see Rocklin carrying his saddle, walking toward the Sun-Up. Shorty Davis hails Rocklin, says somet to him and points to the Sun-Up. Rocklin leaves, walking  faster.
(frowning deeply) He means trouble.
He turns from camera toward the desk.
(still at window) Aw, what do I care.

(turning on him with  cold fury) Listen, I never did have much use  for you. You're a poor specimen at  the best; but as a would-be bad man  you're nothing but a laughing stock.  Why, the way you lied about that  pouch just now wouldn't have deceived  a six-year old.

(harshly) All right, let it go at that. But I  got myself to think of. It wouldn't  suit me at all just now to have you  shown up in public for what you are  by that trouble-shootin' cowhand. My  advice to you is to get out of the  district and stay out. (taking a key from  his vest pocket) You'll find some money in the safe  at the ranch. Take what you need and  put the key in the desk drawer. Now  get.

Rocklin comes down the hall carrying his saddle and looki at the room numbers. As he nears the f.g. he locates the  room he is looking for (it is a room facing toward the re of the Sun-Up). He knocks. Almost immediately the door op and Clara stands there -- flushed and embarrassed.
Oh, Mr. Rocklin --
This is the room in which Clara has arranged to meet Rock who later takes it as his own. SHOT at door as Rocklin steps into the room.
I'm so glad I've found you -- I was  on my way to the Santee and learned  you were in town.
(putting his saddle,  etc., aside) Just got in.
I feel perfectly awful, running after  you like this, but --
You got trouble, eh?
My aunt found out I wrote you and  made a terrible scene --
You haven't signed everything over  to that Garvey, have you?
No -- and because I refused, Auntie  said she would sign an affidavit  that I'm still underage, and then,  as my guardian she can do what she  likes.
Got anything to prove you're not  underage?
(after a slight pause) No -- but Mr. Garvey has a letter  that would prove it. My aunt wrote  it before we came out here.
S'pose we could get it?
He'd never give it to me.
(starts for door) Wait here.
(with a slight start  toward Rocklin) Oh, please -- you -- (she hesitates, not  quite sure what to  say) You won't go getting yourself in  trouble -- I -- I'd rather give up  everything -- I mean --
Rocklin notes her confusion. He regards her with a slight sympathetic smile. Then opens the door and exits.
CLOSE SHOT -- a letter written in a bold feminine hand. I reads:

In answer to your letter of the 25th, kindly be advised t my niece, Clara Caldwell, became of age January 11th of t year. And, although I am no longer her legal guardian, it behooves me, as her nearest kin, to show continued intere in her affairs -- The CAMERA HOLDS LONG ENOUGH for the letter to be read. A now the letter begins to be consumed in a flame as the CA PULLS BACK showing the burning letter in Judge Garvey's h He is standing over the potbellied stove in his office, a Miss Martin is close to him watching the letter burn. Gar finally lets it fall from his fingers onto the top of the stove. He lifts the lid, lets the remains fall inside, an smiles to Miss Martin.
That takes care of that -- (crosses to his desk) Now, I'll draw up an affidavit right  away and everything will be taken  care of as we want it.
(not too enthusiastic) I certainly hope so -- it's not myself  I'm concerned about --
(getting out the papers) -- Of course not.
I can't say I'm very happy about  doing this -- I only hope it works  out for the best.
It's the better choice of two evils --  now let's see -- (begins to write) I, Elizabeth -- (looks at Miss Martin) It is Elizabeth, isn't it?
Yes --
-- Elizabeth Martin, of Danvers,  Massachusetts, do hereby --

The door opens and Rocklin enters. Miss Martin, who has b pacing nervously, stops in her tracks. Garvey, taken  completely by surprise, feigns an affected casualness. Ro eyes them both suspiciously as he slowly closes the door.
(leaning back in his  chair) Well, Mr. Rocklin, this is indeed a  surprise. Didn't expect to see you  so soon. I understood you were riding  for the Santee.
(coldly) That's right.
It is quite obvious to Garvey that Rocklin is here on  business. He turns to Miss Martin.
(to Miss Martin) Perhaps you'd better come back later --
Miss Martin is in accord with that suggestion, and after  giving Rocklin the frigid eye, flounces out, slamming the door. Garvey shakes his head, wipes his brow, and is returning his desk.
SHOT -- door to Garvey's office. Miss Martin has her ear  glued to the panels. Over scene comes Rocklin's voice.
I came for that letter.
Miss Martin reacts.
SHOT -- Garvey and Rocklin.
(calmly) Did you say letter?
That's right -- the one Miss  Caldwell's aunt wrote from out east  sayin' she was of age. Remember?
No -- I'm afraid I don't.
SHOT -- door. Miss Martin reacts with nod of satisfaction and leaves.
Rocklin goes to the filing cabinet where he opens the dra marked "C." As he fingers through the papers, Garvey sits back in his chair, watching.
What is your interest in this letter?
My only interest is getting' it.
You realize what this is, don't you? --  Robbing -- armed robbery at that.
Rocklin pulls open the "M" drawer.
I warn you, you're in for a  disappointment.
Not finding the letter in the "M" drawer, Rocklin goes to the desk and pulls the handle of one of the drawers. It i locked.
Open up.
(has had about enough) Listens, you -- (suddenly controls  himself) There's nothing in there that'd  interest you.
(grimly) I'd like to make up my own mind about  that.
(forces a chuckle) All right -- I'll open it -- just to  convince you I'm not hiding any  letter.

Garvey unlocks the drawer and opens it. It is found to co nothing but two brand new decks of playing cards. The UNOPENED DECKS OF CARDS. BACK TO SCENE. Garvey seems a little too anxious to close the drawer, and before he can do so, Rocklin has one hand inside. Garvey, checked for a second, looks up at Rocklin
What's the idea?
Rocklin slowly withdraws his hand, holding one of the dec
These cards --
(attempting to bluff  it out) Anything wrong in a man having cards  in his possession?
Depends on what kind they are --  'specially when they're under lock  and key.
The two regard each other silently a moment. Now Rocklin  casually slips the deck he holds into his pocket.
(too politely) You're taking those, I presume.
That's right.
He takes a step away. Garvey turns him by touching his ar
(has had almost enough) Now, you look here --
(soberly) You're the one who better start  lookin' -- lookin' for a way out for  killin' Red Caldwell.
(blanches) Caldwell --
(takes up one of the  decks of cards) He found out about these -- and you  went and killed him.
(with an affected  smile and unnatural  calmness) And you believe a story like that?
I will until I hear a better one. (puts deck he holds,  in his pocket) I'll just take this along -- the  district judge at Garden City should  be mighty interested.

He starts around the desk toward the door. From the corne of his eye he catches Garvey reaching for a gun in the mi drawer. Before he can raise it, Rocklin is on him with a  blow that sends Garvey reeling back toward the stove. Rocklin starts for the door again, and just misses being  struck by a chair which Garvey hurls with vicious fury. T chair crashes against a window.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF GARVEY'S OFFICE

text: The sound of breaking glass attracts the attention of pas by, as well as Miss Martin seated in her surrey with Samm the K.C. China-boy.
The two are now fighting in earnest.
of the fight, intercut with townspeople gathering outside

location: STREET IN FRONT OF GARVEY'S OFFICE

text: Dave pulls up in his wagon.

It is pretty well wrecked. Rocklin has Garvey just about  done in. He gives him one final Sunday punch and Garvey g down and stays down. At that moment, Dave and Pap Fossler enter followed by other curious natives.
Say -- looks like you two been  disagreein' 'bout somethin' -- (to Fossler, who has  gone over to Garvey) He ain't daid, is he?
Not permanently, I don't reckon. --  What happened, anyways?
(to Rocklin) You musta found out somethin'.
(with a wink to Dave) I reckon the Judge did, too.
They exit, and almost immediately Miss Martin enters, and after gaping in horror at the appearance of the place, se the Judge, who, having regained consciousness, bestirs hi on the floor.
Oh, dear -- dear -- are you hurt?
(getting up painfully) Get out of my way --
Garvey, on his feet now, makes for the door leading to hi living quarters at the back of the office. Miss Martin fo him.
(haughtily) Now don't you use that tone of voice  to me -- (going through doorway) I'll have you understand I --
She sees the bed and shrieks upon realizing where she is, and backs out quickly, almost catching the door which Gar slams in her face.
Rocklin and Dave as they walk from Garvey's office. Dave a time hopping along against Rocklin's strides.
-- Find out who owns that tobaccy  pouch yet?
(staring straight  ahead) No -- but get hold of Clint Harolday.
Clint -- Is he in on it?
Can't say for sure -- Bring him to  the Sun-Up, and don't take no for an  answer.
Dave leaves and exits from shot in the direction of the s office. Rocklin goes off toward the Sun-Up.

PANNING SHOT. Juan is lounging against the corner of the  building, soberly watching Rocklin's approach. As Rocklin comes into the scene he spots Juan, and stops a moment as though deciding whether or not to question him. During th Juan casually takes his ornamental tobacco pouch from his pocket and begins to roll a cigarette. The CAMERA PANS Rocklin to the side of the building and u the outer stairs.
Rocklin comes through the door and down the hall. He reac his room, and is about to open the door when he hears a  familiar voice inside. He listens.
-- So now you know the truth. And if  you think you can steal him away  from me, you're welcome to try it.
Rocklin frowns and enters.
Rocklin steps into the room, holding the door partly open he focuses his attention on Arly. Clara, who has been sit in the rocker near the window, gets up and is the first t speak.
(anxiously) Did you get it?
Rocklin closes the door.
No -- but I don't think it's gonna  matter much -- you go on back to the  K.C. and I'll be out in the mornin'  and take you with me to Garden City  to see the district judge.
But I hate putting you to that  trouble.
No trouble at all -- I'm going anyway.
(casually) You look like you've been fighting.
(soberly) What are you doin' here?
I was just telling Miss Caldwell  about -- well -- you and me.
(his eyes narrowing) What about, you an' me?
(sensing the static  in the atmosphere) I think I'd better be going...
(turning quickly from  Arly) Just a minute -- (glances at Arly) What all has she been tellin' you?
(embarrassed) Oh -- oh, really I'd rather not --
(interrupting) Go ahead, tell him -- (looks at Rocklin and  goes on defiantly) -- and I dare him to deny it.
Deny what?
That she was with you last night at  the cabin in the mountains.
Well -- why should I deny it?...
(quickly) And didn't you make love to me?
(this is getting a  bit thick for him) Make love to you --
(forcing her point) You didn't kiss me -- I suppose?
Did you expect me to deny that, too?
(smiles at Clara) You see?
(to Clara) Now, maybe you ought to hear what  I've got to say --
Clara is terribly hurt, but struggles to be grown-up abou it.
Please -- you needn't explain. After  all, it really isn't any of my  business, is it?
(in the pause he looks  at Arly) You little --
(quickly) That's it -- start swearin'-- (to Clara) Just like a man.
If there wasn't a lady here, I'd do  more to you than swear.
I don't know how I can ever thank  you for trying to help me. I do  appreciate it ever so much -- (to Arly) Don't think too harshly of me, will  you -- I --
Clara can say no more without breaking. So she turns away quickly and hurries out the door. Rocklin does a slow bur as he glares at Arly.
(sincerely -- after a  pause) She's lovely, isn't she? -- So sweet --  honest, and helpless.
Rocklin makes no reply.
Pity you didn't fall in love with  her, instead of me.
Arly is being ridiculous now. He ignores her remarks and  concentrates his attention on one of his hands -- he may  have sprained it slightly in the fight.
You might's well know right now that  you or no woman is ever goin' to get  me.
Don't be so sure -- I don't think  I'm doin' so badly.
Don't you?
Don't you know?
I know there ain't a dirty trick you  wouldn't play to get what you want.
(smiling) I always get what I want.
She takes a folded piece of paper out of her pocket and d it on the dresser as Rocklin watches her.
-- See? (opens the door) -- 'Bye now --

The door closes. Rocklin stands a moment. Now curiosity b him to the dresser where he takes up the paper and unfold it. CLARA'S LETTER. The torn pieces have all been sorted and  pasted together on a sheet of paper BACK TO SCENE. Rocklin holds the letter. He is mad. He sh his head -- What a gal --- Now he is almost smiling -- al He folds the letter -- puts it in his pocket. Takes off h gun-belt and hangs it over the rocker near the window, an stretches out on the bed, as we
ON Clara hurrying toward the front door in a suppressed s of excitement. She has presumably just arrived at the ran in advance of Miss Martin. She enters the house after a g toward the gate.
Clara enters hastily and beats a path to the door of her  room.
The door flies open. Clara bursts in, closing the door in the same movement. Her eyes swing to someone o.s. and she freezes to the spot.

Miss Martin, standing by the window, cold and threatening She has not taken the time to remove her hat. After a mom pause, she moves slowly toward Clara. The CAMERA PANS WITH her into a TWO SHOT. Clara, her back pressing harder and harder against the door, becomes more terrified at the other's approach. Miss Martin appraises girl a short moment and now suddenly slaps her hard acros the face. Clara opens her mouth, about to scream, but eve stifles this impulse under the cold stare of her aunt.
(quietly but viciously) Whatever is to become of you?
Clara can only stare as one under an hypnotic spell.
Have you no sense of pride, or  decency? Throwing yourself at that --  that wretch, like any shameless hussy.
Clara hasn't moved.
I thought we'd done with him -- but  no -- you have to run to him and  tell him all our business --
Clara merely gasps for a breath of air, but Miss Martin,  thinking her about to speak, goes on, more forcefully now
Don't you dare deny it -- you know  very well you told him about that  letter I wrote Mr. Garvey.
Clara remains silent.
Didn't you? --
Clara, now utterly broken, moves away. Miss Martin, her e still rivited on the girl, follows.
Didn't you?

The office has been more or less cleaned up since the fig Garvey is discovered near the window. He has cleaned hims up but bears some evidence of the fight. He is reading a  letter as Sammy, the K.C. China-boy, stands waiting near door. LETTER. The message is written in the same bold hand of M Martin already seen in the previous letter: Mr. Garvey, I have just learned that despicable Rocklin person intend to take Clara to Garden City in the morning -- evidently have you investigated. I thought you had better know abou it. E.M. BACK TO SCENE. Garvey puts the message in his pocket as h addresses Sammy.
Tell Miss Martin that I'll take care  of everything.
-- You take clare of evelything.
On Rocklin, stretched across the bed, examining the cards the light of a lamp.
Garvey comes from around the building's corner and peers  furtively through the darkness toward the lighted windows Rocklin's room.

The area in front of the Sun-Up. Dave's wagon pulls up to the hitching rail in front of the saloon. Clint, stripped his gun, is driving with Dave, alertly watching him. They get down from the wagon and Dave prods Clint toward the c of the building.

Garvey has left the spot where we saw him look up to Rock window. We now see him as he rounds a rear corner of the  building and goes toward the outer stairs leading to the Up's second floor. He starts up the steps and stops almos immediately and stares o.s.
From Garvey's ANGLE as he sees Dave bringing Clint from a in front of the building toward the stairway.

Garvey steps quickly to the ground and takes up a positio around the roar corner. He watches the two men approach t stairway and go up. He moves out of the shot now, going t the street. The CAMERA HOLDS on the corner, and we see Ta come into view, as though from nowhere, and take the exac position at the building's corner vacated by Garvey only moment before. It is apparent that he is watching Garvey, and after a momentary pause he too moves stealthily out o the scene.

PANNING SHOT on Rocklin asleep. He is fully dressed, as w last saw him, with the exception of his boots. He is stre full length on top of the covers. His gun-belt still hang over the rocker, close to the open window. A knock on the door brings him to a sitting position.
Come in --
CAMERA PANS TO door as Clint enters reluctantly, followed the triumphant Dave.
Here he is, Rock. Caught him jist in  time near the Santee. Headed fer  out, I'd say.
Sit down, Clint. (to Dave, as he reaches  into his pocket) How about goin' down below an' havin'  one on me?
He tosses Dave a coin, who catches it. Then Rocklin puts his boots.
(delighted) Well, now -- that's right thoughtful --  Holler if you need me.
Dave exits.
(belligerently, as he  stands near the window) What's this all about?
(calmly, as he stands  up) It ain't gonna do you any good to  get all het up and tough, kid --
Rocklin begins rolling a cigarette as he moves toward Cli
I just want to ask you a few questions --  that's all.

An unidentifiable form is seen moving through the darknes toward the outer stairway. As it nears the stairway, the  CAMERA MOVES IN so that as the mysterious figure begins  stealthily up the stairs, we see only the feet through th rungs. The CAMERA THEN PANS QUICKLY AND ZOOMS INTO A CLOSE SHOT Juan, across the alley. And now through Juan's eyes we wa the ascent of the mysterious intruder: The Mexican's line vision gradually raises, then the eyes slowly move across the camera as the dark figure proceeds along to the rear  portion of the verandah.
Rocklin finishes rolling his cigarette and lights it.
I told you once, I don't know who  owns that pouch-- and I don't know  who shot you.
(calmly) Forget it -- that's not what I want  to talk to you about, anyway.
(harshly) Well, what do you want to talk about?  Come on, get it over with.
The mysterious form has moved past the darkened windows a the verandah and is nearing Rocklin's lighted room -- sto close to the open window.
SHOT -- Rocklin and Clint.
Clint -- I want you to tell me why  Garvey murdered Red Caldwell --
Clint tenses -- stares -- finds breathing difficult.
You know -- don't you?
(shaking) Me? No!
Oh yes you do. (advancing on him) And you're going to tell me all about  it.
I don't know nothing, I tell you --  I --
Rocklin slaps Clint's face open-handed, throwing him off  balance, then grabs him by the shirt front.
Talk!
I tell ya, I...
(hitting him again) Talk!

Completely terrified, Clint opens his mouth as if about t speak. Suddenly he sees something out of the shot over  Rocklin's shoulder and his expression changes. Rocklin lo quickly in the same direction.
window. A gloved hand has come out of the dark and is rea through the window for Rocklin's gun in the belt which is hanging over the chair.

Clint and Rocklin. The latter is still looking toward the window. With a swift movement Clint picks up the water ju from the washstand and brings it down on Rocklin's head. Rocklin falls out of shot, Clint turns to the window with triumphant smile. Suddenly his expression changes.
(in a hoarse scream) No! No, don't!
There is a shot from o.s. and Clint's hands go to his sto With a gasp of pain he doubles up and collapses on the fl
window. The hand of the killer pitches the gun toward Roc and disappears.

Lined up at the bar are Dave, Pap Fossler, Shorty Davis a a few others. Cap is in his usual place. At the poker tab are Doc Riding, Sam Haynes, Ab Jenkins and one or two oth The shot has evidently been heard, for everything seems t have stopped, and Dave and Pap Fussier are looking up tow the ceiling, as are others. Now Dave snaps back to life - gulps down his drink, and hurries toward the stairs. As h starts up, the others move slowly in the same direction.

Rocklin is on the floor, groggy. He shakes his head, and his senses return, he picks up the gun and just gets to h feet as Dave rushes in. Dave sees Clint's body on the floor -- notices the gun in Rocklin's hand. He opens his mouth to speak but nothing c out. All he can do is stare and grimace. The sound of hur feet comes from the hall, and presently the mob closes in crowding the room and the hall. Pap Fossler, who has been one of the first to enter, knee over Clint. During this, there are general ad libs from the crowd.
What happened? Who is it? Clint  Harolday -- Etc.
Where's Doc Riding?
Get the Doc. Hey, Doc -- He was down  below. Here he is.
Doc's voice is heard from the hall as he makes his way th the jam.
Here I am --
Look out, men -- Let the Doc through.  Etc.
Doc riding comes through the crowd, kneels beside Pap Fos He needs only a glance to know he can be of no use.
(breaking the silence) Somebody better fetch Harolday.
Shorty's already gone for him.
(getting up) Better get Arly, too.
A voice is heard from the hall.
She was at the hotel a while ago.
(looking down at Clint  and shaking his head) He was only a kid.
Rocklin, still holding his gun as he stares down at Clint body o.s. Now he studies the faces of the mob.
of the crowd. There is nothing but a sea of hostile faces
What's goin' on here -- gang way --
The crowd parts to admit Jackson, who comes stalking in  followed by Judge Garvey.
What's the trouble here --
He stops abruptly as he sees Clint's body. Now he levels eyes on Rocklin.
(with a bitter smile) I warned you, didn't I? -- Well, I  guess this is the last trouble you'll  ever make in this town. (extending his hand) Hand over that gun.
Just a minute, now --
He steps back so no one is behind him. And there is somet about his manner and tone that urges Jackson to use  discretion.
(to the crowd,  generally) I know it looks bad -- but I didn't  kill the kid.
The crowd stares in skeptical silence. Even Dave thinks  Rocklin is lying, and now does his best to protect his fr
I believe you. (to the others) His gun was layin' over there on the  floor when I come in and --
(cutting in) No it wasn't -- It was right in my  hand -- like it is now.
Dave winces.
If you didn't know him -- then who  did?
I don't know -- (looks at garvey) But I'm going to find out.

Harolday, followed by Shorty Davis, is making his way dow the hall from the inner stair landing. As he nears the cr gathered at Rocklin's door, Juan comes into view down the hall, having just entered through the door leading out on the verandah.
(as he nears Rocklin's  door) Where is he? -- Where's my boy?
Harolday enters, over the ad libs of the mob, followed by Shorty Davis. During the following action, Juan enters an stands near the door, silently taking in everything.
Harolday, as he sees Clint's body and stops dead in horro He turns to Rocklin.
(with cold violence) You murderer.
I didn't do it, Mr. Harolday.
(quickly) Then who did?
(from crowd) He had a gun in his hand when we  come in.
(smoothly) And I'll bet it's the same one the  bullet that killed Clint came out  of.
Rocklin gives Garvey a hard, slow look.
Well, what do you say to that?
He's right.
You admit it.
Yeah -- but that still don't say I  killed him.
Aw, take him away -- Liar -- Lock  him up, Sheriff -- The yellow-bellied --  Etc.

head_text.subj: ON ARLY AS SHE PUSHES HER WAY THROUGH THE CROWD

text: She stares down at Clint. An expression of pity comes ove her. Now she looks coldly at Rocklin.
(softly) Why did you do it?
with Rocklin in f.g.
I didn't.
He admits it was his gun that shot  him.
(whose eyes haven't  left Rocklin's) But you didn't fire it.
That's right.
What happened?
(slowly) Clint and me was having a bit of an  argument.
(quickly) What about?

(searching for words) About whether he was going to help  clear up a few things that's been  bothering me and some others 'round  these parts. (looking at Garvey) For instance -- who it was shot Red  Caldwell.
Caldwell!
(still at Garvey) And the K.C. foreman. And who took  that shot at me up at Table-Top last  night. And why certain people are so  anxious to get rid of the Caldwell  girl.
How would Clint know about all that?
(harshly) He's lying. He's trying to cover up  for killing my boy.
(encouraged by the  support) Quit stalling, Rocklin.
He makes a tentative movement toward Rocklin but Arly  intervenes.
Wait a minute -- he's get a right to  be heard. (to Rocklin) Well, we're listenin'.
Well -- Clint was getting' all set  to talk, when -- somebody snuck up  along the verandah there and pulled  the gun out o' my belt... (indicating the belt  on chair) ... and let him have it.
There is a moment's amazed silence. Then the crowd breaks into derisive comment.
What a story! What an alibi! String  him up, the heel! Etc.
(grinning) You'll have to think up something  better than that Rocklin.
with Garvey in f.g.

(smoothly) Don't be a fool, Rocklin. You know  you can't get away with a yarn like  that. Why don't you save yourself  and everyone else a lot of trouble  by surrendering to the Sheriff? After  all, it isn't such a crime in these  parts to kill a man in self-defense.
Self-defense?
Everyone knows what Clint was like.  He probably lost his head and pulled  a gun on you, like he did at the Sun- Up that night. Wasn't that it?

(grimly; after a little  pause) No, that wasn't it. And till I do  what I got to do, I ain't surrenderin'  to anybody -- least of all to your  pal here. (indicates sheriff) If I got to be shot for knowing too  much, it ain't going to be in the  back, in a framed-up jail-break.
Arly, who has been staring at Rocklin in frowning  bewilderment.
But if someone's trying to kill you,  why didn't they do it just now? Why  did they have to kill Clint?
Rocklin.
Guess they wanted to get Clint, too.  Doin' it this way they get us both.  Clint first -- an' me afterwards --  like I jus' said.
with Garvey in f.g. Close beside him are Pap and Dave, wh watches Garvey closely.
Quit fancy talk. Who's "they?"
I might be able to tell you that  later.
(quickly) No you won't -- because you're comin'  with me.
(raises his gun) Am I?
The crowd tenses. Rocklin eyes them grimly.
The first one that moves -- gets it.

He moves over to the open window, and with his gun levele on the mob, steps out onto the verandah. Once outside, he suddenly lets the window fall and disappears. A shot from Jackson's gun shatters a pane, during which time there ha been a rush to the window. It is Arly and Dave who reach first, and feigning an attempt to raise the window, they  momentarily delay pursuit.

head_text.subj: AT THE DOOR LEADING FROM THE ROOM

text: There is the inevitable jam as the pushing, yelling crowd all try to exit at once.
Rocklin, as he picks himself off the ground, having dropp from the verandah. He starts quickly away.
SHOOTING INTO the room, we see Arly and Dave shoved to on side by Jackson and Garvey. The window goes up and Jackso steps out, followed by Garvey, Harolday, Arly, Dave, and  others.
The human jam has been broken, and now the mob dashes wil toward the stairway, and verandah exit in the b.g.

The hitching rail in front of the Sun-Up. There are a doz or so horses tied up to it and close to it is Dave's team and wagon. Rocklin comes from around the corner of the  building and races to the hitching rail.

Jackson and Garvey come from around the corner of the por followed by Harolday, Arly, Dave, and others. At the stai they collide with some of the men who have raced down the hall, only to reach the stairway at the same moment. Ther is another jam on the landing as the mob all try to get d at once.
He has cut the lines of the horses tied to the rail. We s him cutting the last line and fire into the air. The hors rare and stampede.
And now there is a state of utter confusion as the mob an horses rush in all directions as the men try to retrieve  their mounts. Rocklin is no where in evidence.
(sarcastically) Well, Sheriff -- you certainly are  to be congratulated.
(harassed) Look, Mr. Harolday -- you saw what  happened --
(deeply concerned) Never mind that -- Let's get going  for Garden City -- that's where he's  headed for.
You sure?
I'm positive.
Dave climbs into his wagon behind the group as Jackson ex quickly.

At hitching rail. There are four or five horses tied up h Arly and Juan enter and mount their horses, and almost  immediately Garvey and Harolday come hurrying into the sc after two of the other horses.
(shouts from her horse) Where do you think he's gone?
Before either of the two men can answer, Jackson's voice heard shouting o.s.
All right, men -- follow me --

The CAMERA PANS AROUND, getting Jackson, now mounted, as  others come riding in. He rares his horse around and star away followed by the mob, including our principals. They not get very far when Dave's wagon comes into the shot, g hell-bent in pursuit.

location: ROAD NEAR EDGE OF SANTA INEZ

text: The posse riding hard, with Dave's wagon following.
Dave, half standing as he urges his team on. Behind him a the closed flaps of the wagon top.
as a hand reaches out from between the flaps and grasps t reins. Dave takes it, and looks wildly around -- falls ba on the seat.
CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Dave, smiling broadly. Rockl is pulling hard on the reins.
I mighta knowed you'd do somethin'  like this. (as Rocklin slows the  team) What are we doin'?
Headin' for the K.C.
With that Rocklin starts swinging the team around.

head_text.subj: ON THE WAGON AS IT SWINGS AROUND AND BECOMES LOST IN THE

text: Sammy, the China-boy, is nervously knocking on Miss Marti door. It opens and Miss Martin is seen slipping a robe ov her long Mother Hubbard nightgown, with cap to match.
(impatiently) Now -- what is it?

Sammy points o.s. -- Miss Martin looks and freezes. As she moves down the hall, the CAMERA PANS WITH her unti it gets two men standing near the entrance door. Now the CAMERA MOVES IN TO A THREE SHOT and we recognize  George Clews and his brother, Bob. Bob, his wrist bandage takes off his hat at Miss Martin's approach, and George  noticing, does likewise.
The name's Clews, ma'am -- Mr. Garvey  sent us out --
(eagerly) Said you were expectin' trouble with  that Rocklin.
I am. (acidly to George) -- But I'm wondering if you're up to  it. I noticed you didn't fare so  well with him yesterday.
He was drunk --
(quickly) Yeah -- But I'm sober now.
Well, see that you stay that way.
Don't worry, ma'am -- I've jus' bin  waitin' to get even with that saddle- bum.
He opens the door.
(with that oily smile) We'll be close-by.
(confidently) You bet.
They start out.

Clara is seen in her nightgown, listening at the door to room. The sound of the outer door closing comes over the  scene and she hurries to her bed and feigns sleep, and ju in time, for the door opens and Miss Martin sticks her he in, and satisfied that Clara is sleeping, exits.

A raspy voice is heard coming out of the darkness singing ribald song of the periods. And now Old Zeke, riding his  burro, comes into view. As he passes close to the camera, PAN and get the posse coming out of the darkness in the  opposite direction Zeke is travelling. As the posse pulls up to Zeke, the CAMERA MOVES IN on a g including Zeke, Jackson, Garvey, Harolday.
Seen anybody ridin' hard for Garden  City.
Bin on the road since sundown --  ain't seen a livin' soul -- be he  man or beast.
He mighta taken the cutoff through  Jaw Bone Canyon.
After that storm? -- He'd never make  it.
There's only one other place he might  have gone -- the K.C.
You think so?
(very definitely) I'm positive.
That's what you said before.
(shouting to the posse  milling around) To the K.C., men.
The posse swings around and starts back toward Santa Inez
Arly watches the posse, then turns to Juan.
(excitedly) Take me through the canyon.
It is dangerous, senorita.
But if we get through we'll beat  them to the K.C.
You would risk your life for Senor  Rocklin?

Arly does not answer in words. But Juan sees the answer i her eyes. Now she tosses her head defiantly and swings he horse off the road in the direction of the canyon. Juan  watches a moment, then spurs his mount after her, as we
On Clara, tossing fitfully in her bed. Suddenly she sits as an idea begins to take form in her mind. Now she hurri out of bed, moves stealthily to the door and goes out, le her door open.

ON door to Miss Martin's room. Clara comes down the hall the door. She puts her ear close and listens. Now she ope it cautiously and peers inside. The door to her room is  slammed o.s. by a sporadic draft. It startles the girl an she quickly closes Miss Martin's door and hurries away.
ON the posse, riding hell-bent.

Arly and Julio, as they slowly pick their way along the  difficult trail, skirting a roaring torrent. Julio is lea and close behind him Arly is having a time negotiating th unsteady ground of a landslide.
She notices Julio staring o.s. and slowly shaking his hea
Afraid?
Julio nods his head slowly, deliberately.
Only for you -- you must not do this --  I will go through from here alone.
A faint smile of admiration brushes Arly's face.
No, -- we're going through together.
Arly lashes her horse away. Julio realizes the futileness further pleading and now moves his horse out after Arly.
The wagon with Dave and Rocklin coming out of the night.
Dave is driving the team for all it is worth. Rocklin is  looking back. He turns to Dave.
You can ease up now.
We're just about there.
A wooden gate is swung closed across the roadway. On the  gate is a crudely printed weather-beaten sign: K.C. RANCH Over the scene comes the SOUND of the wagon approaching.

head_text.subj: THE WAGON PULLS UP TO THE GATE

text: Rocklin hops out, opens the gate. Dave drives the wagon  through. As Rocklin lets go the gate, it swings closed of its own accord.
The shed is a short distance from the Caldwell house. Bob Clews is standing at a corner of the shed looking o.s. Ov the scene comes the SOUND of the wagon.
(peering into shed) Hey, George -- George, get up.

The wagon moving slowly through the cottonwoods, along th drive not far from the house. It stops now, and the CAMER MOVES CLOSER to get Dave and Rocklin as they leave the te and start stealthily toward the house seen in the moonlig in the b.g.

We pick up Clara in the act of nervously pinning on her h in the dim light of a small lamp. She is fully dressed, a once the hat is on, she looks around anxiously for her to coat which she finds in the closet. She takes the coat an starts hurriedly toward the lamp, sitting on a small tabo near the door. As she bends over to blow it out, her eyes raise and she freezes.

head_text.subj: MISS MARTIN HAS JUST OPENED THE DOOR AND STANDS THERE STA

text: Now she snaps the door closed without removing her eyes f Clara, and starts forward. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the two. Clara stands as one under an hypnotic spell.
(in a very low tone) You vile, ungrateful strumpet --  running away in the night, like a  deceitful sneak-thief --
(unrestrained) Yes -- I'm running away -- and it's  all your fault -- you're the one  who's been deceitful and sneaking --  and don't think I don't know what  you intend doing.
(very controlled) -- And don't think I don't know what  you intend doing.
(crying, as she moves  away) I don't care -- I'm not ashamed of  it -- and nothing you can say or do  is going to stop me.
(hardly above a whisper) You little fool -- if you go to Garden  City with that man -- you stand to  lose everything.
(stops pacing) But why? -- Why are you being so  secretive? -- If you know something,  why don't you tell me?

head_text.subj: ON DAVE AND ROCKLIN AT THE WINDOW LISTENING

text: (nods and mumbles to  himself) Yeah -- why don't you? --
Rocklin quickly shushes Dave.

(Unmindful of the  presence of the men) All right, I'll tell you -- Rocklin  is a nephew of the late Mr. Caldwell.  And, as nearest of kin, he stands to  get everything -- according to the  will. Because you are not the old  man's niece, but only his grand-niece.

head_text.subj: DAVE AND ROCKLIN AT THE WINDOW LISTENING

text: Rocklin turned up unexpectedly --
And you and Mr. Garvey knew the truth  all the time?
Yes.
If Dave keeps quiet any longer he'll burst. He spins Rock around and speaks in his natural voice.
-- And you knew the truth all the  time, too -- didn't you? -- No wonder  you stuck around --
From Rocklin's expression it is quite apparent to Dave th he is right.

Both women are staring dumbly toward the window. Now the  realization that she has been overheard staggers Miss Mar She utters a stifled scream and, seeing Rocklin starting  through the window, runs from the room.
Get in here and take care of her.
Dave scrambles through the window and hurries in pursuit Miss Martin. Rocklin is at Clara's side.
Bushes near the house. George and Bob Clews are crouched, watching.
Come on --
They move out.

location: ROAD BETWEEN SANTA INEZ AND THE KC RANCH

text: The posse riding hard.
We see Arly and Julio as they descend a steep embankment  toward the raging torrent. They both are riding Julio's h
Arly and Julio; Arly seated behind Julio, considerably  disheveled and sobbing.
(comfortingly) You are crying, senorita --?
(lying bravely) No.
(knows she is) It is too bad we lose your horse.  She was good horse, for sure.
If only we make it in time.
As they move away into a longer shot, a huge boulder come crashing down the canyon side, across their path, and tum with a great roar and splash into the torrent.
Clara is talking feverishly to Rocklin.
-- And I heard one of them tell my  aunt not to worry, that he was just  as anxious as she was to get even  with you.
Dave enters from the hall carrying Miss Martin over his  shoulder. He has her wrapped in a sheet and bound up in  tassled curtain cord.
(as Clara and Rocklin  react) This is the only way I could handle  her.
The Clews are around here some place --  Garvey sent 'em out.
George and Bob Clews at the window. George has his gun  leveled, and a dirty smile twists his face.
You bet we're around.
The CAMERA PULLS BACK as George Clews climbs into the roo followed by Bob. They disarm both Rocklin and Dave as Cla watches helplessly, and Miss Martin struggles in her wrap
(to Bob) Untie her.
(to Dave) Untie her.
Dave puts Miss Martin down and begins undoing her as Bob  covers him with his gun.

location: ROAD BETWEEN SANTA INEZ AND THE KC RANCH

text: The posse riding.
Arly and Juan leave the hazardous trail behind and now st across the flat on a run.
Dave has unwrapped Miss Martin and she gets to her feet  bristling.
(to Bob) Now tie him up. (indicates Dave)
(quickly, as she picks  up the tassled cord) I'll take part in this -- you -- you  hairy beast.
Bob Clews tosses the sheet over Dave's head. And as Dave  struggles,
Rocklin thinks he has George off guard and makes a pass a him. But George is on the alert and strikes Rocklin on th head with his pistol.

head_text.subj: ON CLARA AS ROCKLIN GOES DOWN

text: She utters a choked cry and falls to the floor in a faint
as Miss Martin comes to Clara and kneels beside her.
Help me get her to the bed.
of the room. Bob Clews has Dave securely tied, and now as Miss Martin in getting Clara to the bed.
(indicating Rocklin  on the floor) What'll we do with 'em?
Take them in to Mr. Garvey and tell  him I must see him at once.
(triumphantly) We'll dump them right in the Judge's  lap.
George Clews picks up the unconscious Rocklin.
(still administering  to Clara) Hadn't you better tie him, too?
(to Bob, after a  second's pause) Get some more rope.
Bob hurries to do so.
The posse riding.
Dave's wagon. Bob Clews is seen dumping Dave into the rea of the wagon. George Clews stands near him with Rocklin's unconscious form over his shoulder. Now he puts Rocklin i
Get our horses and meet me at the  gate.
Bob runs after the horses. George gets onto the wagon sea swings the team around and heads for the gate.

location: FLAT LAND NEAR THE KC RANCH

text: Arly and Juan riding hard.

George Clews sits in the wagon waiting for Bob, who now c out of the darkness with their horses. He dismounts, ties the horses to the back of the wagon, comes around in fron to the gate. He is about to swing it open when he looks p the camera at Arly and Juan, who now pull up to the outsi of the gate. Arly dismounts quickly, her gun in her hand. Bob Clews backs up toward the wagon as Arly walks through gate.
of Arly.
George Clews on the wagon seat. He is smiling and is goin to try to bluff it out.
(to Arly) What are you doin' with that gun,  Arly?
Arly.
Get down from there before I show  you.
Rocklin has regained consciousness and listens.
Now listen, Arly -- this ain't your  wagon --
Neither is it yours -- Get down out  of there -- before I knock you down.
Rocklin recognizes Arly's voice. Now he raises himself up over the tailboard and falls out.
The horses tied in back shy as Rocklin falls to the groun
Arly, as she takes it and starts toward the rear of the w
He no more than gets it out when a knife whirls in from o getting him in the small of the back.
He sits calmly astride his horse, his gun leveled on Geor Clews.
Arly is cutting the rope binding Rocklin.
-- And they're headed this way and  should get here any minute --
Rocklin gets to his feet. Arly notices something shining the ground where Rocklin lay. She picks it up. It is the  tobacco pouch with the steer's head of hammered silver.
Where'd you get this?
(taking the pouch) That belongs to the man who shot at  me on Table-Top -- Dave found it.
On Dave's Wrapped form, kicking the wagon tailboard. Arly head appears between the flaps above the tailboard and as Dave groans and kicks, she takes her knife and slits the  rope binding him.
Rocklin has come to George clew and we see him wrest the from his hand and yank George down from the wagon seat. O down, he lets him have a hard right that sends him sprawl

head_text.subj: ON GEORGE CLEWS GETTING UP OFF THE GROUND AND ROCKLIN CLO

text: They start fighting viciously. Arly rushes in crying wild
(trying to stop Rocklin) You've got to get away -- they'll be  here -- they'll catch you --
Rocklin. There is but one thought in his enraged mind --  Clews. He tears into him again.

head_text.subj: ON ARLY AS DAVE JOINS HER

text: (frantically) You've got to stop him -- he's got  to get away.

head_text.ToD: AS DAVE AND ARLY FUTILELY ATTEMPT TO BREAK IT

head_text.subj: ON DAVE AS HE GETS IN THE WAY OF ONE THAT SITS HIM DOWN
ON THE FIGHT AS ROCKLIN GETS IN A SUNDAY PUNCH THAT SENDS
GEORGE BACKWARD INTO A SHALLOW DITCH OUT OF SIGHT
ON GEORGE CLEWS LYING UNCONSCIOUS IN THE DITCH

text: The posse approaching.
Rocklin, Arly, Dave, Rocklin is about done in from the fi
(anxiously) Come on -- let's git goin' --
(as he walks to wagon) Where's the girl?
Back at the house --
We've got to get her.
You haven't time -- they're coming --  don't you believe me? --
(to Dave) Come on --
Arly's plea goes unheeded and he starts away toward the h on the run.
(mutters) Stubborn as an ole mule. (shouts) You're puttin' a rope around your  neck --
Dave runs after Rocklin.
Get him -- (indicates Bob Clews) -- out of sight, and follow me.
She takes up the reins now and swings the team around and off the road into the thickness of the trees.
Rocklin and Dave. They are approaching the house warily.
(softly) But what'll we do with the ole lady?
Anything you like.
I'd like to pizen her.
Arly is seated on the wagon seat looking toward the gate Juan comes in on his horse.
(pointing o.s.) Look.
At gate. The posse rides up. The gate is swung open and t ride through.
At wagon. Arly jumps to the ground and speaks to Juan.
Come on.
As she starts toward the house, Juan dismounts and follow
The posse comes riding in. Jackson, Garvey, Harolday, and few others dismount and go toward the door.
as they move stealthily into a spot shielded by undergrow which gives them full view of the front and one side of t house.
Miss Martin is coming into the room with a glass and a pi for Clara, who is still stretched on the bed.
If you'll just take this -- you'll  go to sleep --
The sound of someone knocking on the front door comes ove the scene. Miss Martin exits hurriedly.
At front door. Miss Martin opens the door, confronting Ja and the group. She is bewildered.
Evenin' ma'am -- hate to bother you  like this, but --
(seeing Garvey,  interrupts) I'm so glad you've come, Mr. Garvey,  the most awful -- (as though seeing the  crowd for the first  time) -- Why -- what are all these people  doing here?
We're after Rocklin -- has he been  here?
(smugly) Oh yes -- here and gone.
What!
(astounded) Gone --
(triumphantly) Yes -- the two men you sent out are  taking him and that horrid old man  back to town.
The Clewses -- funny we didn't see  them.
Somethin' musta gone wrong -- We  better fan out and see what's goin'  on.
(quickly) Don't leave, Mr. Garvey -- I've got  to talk with you, privately --
As all but Garvey and Harolday go back to their horses, G speaks.
But, madam --
It's very important.
Garvey looks at Harolday in a manner evidencing his dista and impatience.
We'll go on and meet you in town.
Perhaps you'd better. (calls to Jackson  o.s.) I'll meet you in town, Jackson.
Right -- come on, men.
The sound of running horses comes over the scene as Harol hurries away and Garvey enters the house.

head_text.subj: ON HAROLDAY AS HE GOES TO HIS HORSE

text: He starts to mount, but instead leads the horse into the  bushes close to where Juan and Arly are watching.
Miss Martin and Garvey have been talking. Garvey paces  nervously.
(quickly, as he turns  to Miss Martin) -- And you're positive he knows  everything?
Absolutely everything -- He was  standing at the window all the time --  the scoundrel.
Rocklin has his ear glued to the door. He can't help but  smile at Miss Martin's reference to him. Dave is behind t curtain at the window, watching the outside. Clara is clo to Rocklin.
(whispers) You better get back on the bed -- in  case they come in here.
Clara tiptoes away.
Arly and Juan, as they watch Harolday approach the house go to the hall window.
Garvey and Miss Martin. Garvey is still pacing very nervo He is trying to think of his next move.
If you were to ask me, I think the  best thing to do is --
Garvey stops and glares.
(irritably) I'm not asking you -- and don't bother  me with your silly questions -- we've  got to do something besides talk.
(drawing herself up) You mean -- you have to do something.
Garvey stops and looks at her again.
-- This was all your idea, remember.
(tossing it off) My idea -- that's all you know about  it.
It is open and Rocklin stands there looking o.s.
If there's anybody else in on it --  speak up, Judge.

head_text.subj: ON GARVEY AS HE WHIPS AROUND AND STARES AT ROCKLIN

text: Well -- I do declare --
She can say no more.
Rocklin steps away from the door, where Dave and Clara no stand. He has Garvey covered. Dave is pointing his gun, a grimacing at Miss Martin.
At hall window -- on Harolday watching.
Garvey is stepping back, in a cold sweat, toward Miss Mar as Rocklin advances toward him.
(to Garvey, quite  casually) Talk.
Miss Martin opens her mouth, about to speak.
of Dave.
(blasting, to Miss  Martin) Not you.
Miss Martin. Her mouth snaps shut like a trap.
Garvey, Rocklin, Miss Martin. Rocklin takes the tobacco p out of his pocket.
(to Garvey) Ever see that before?
(blanches) No -- it's not mine.
Tell me whose it is.
(shaking) No -- no -- I don't know --

Harolday at hall window. He raises his gun -- he is about fire when a knife whirls out of nowhere and sticks in the window frame, inches from Harolday's head. He spins aroun and stares wildly here and there at the darkness.

head_text.subj: GROUNDS AND BUSHES NEAR THE FRONT DOOR

text: There is no one in evidence.
Drop that gun.

head_text.subj: ON HAROLDAY AT THE HALL WINDOW

text: He drops the gun. Arly and Juan come in to him. Arly has covered. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to a WIDER ANGLE, getting the front door as it is opened by Rocklin, who evidently heard Arly
Arly is prodding Harolday into the scene.
(to Rocklin) He was just getting ready to finish  you off, through that window.
Harolday is herded inside, close to Garvey and Miss Marti
(almost enjoying this) You seem to like to do business  through windows, Mr. Harolday.
In the pause Harolday remains sneeringly silent.
You're not Clint's killer, by any  chance --
(cutting in) By one bad chance -- (glares at Harolday) Juan saw you do it.
Harolday looks at Juan, who slowly nods.
Well, now we're gettin' some place --
He brings up the tobacco pouch. But before he can ask abo it, Arly speaks.
That pouch is his -- (indicates Harolday) Juan made it for him a long time  ago. (to Juan) Didn't you?
Juan nods. Rocklin, with a sudden transition, speaks to Harolday in hard, threatening tone.
(to Harolday) Why did you kill Caldwell?

Harolday doesn't answer. He finally looks at Garvey in  desperation. Perspiration runs down Garvey's forehead.  Suddenly Harolday makes a mad dash for the door. Rocklin  shoots, but Arly pushes his arm and sends the shot wild.  Rocklin looks at her in amazement. Julio hurries out.

On Harolday as he rushes madly across the clearing toward the bushes where his horse waits. The CAMERA SWINGS BACK to the porch in time to catch Juli crossing it in pursuit of Harolday. Arly and Rocklin come through the open door and stand on the porch watching.

head_text.subj: THE BUSHES WHERE HAROLDAY'S HORSE IS HIDDEN

text: They see Julio disappear in the brush. For a moment nothi happens; now Harolday's horse bolts out, riderless, and  gallops away. Now Julio comes slowly into view. He moves  slowly and deliberately back toward the house.
Julio comes in to Rocklin and Arly. The three exchange  significant glances as we
In the hall are Clara and Miss Martin, Rocklin, Arly and  Julio, Dave and Garvey. Garvey is seated and has evidentl been talking in the way of confession.

-- Harolday wanted the K.C. like he  wanted the Santee and the Hardman  place, for his land scheme -- He  planned on breaking up the ranches  into small holdings and selling to  dirt farmers. He pretended to be on  the outs with me so I could get  Caldwell's confidence. And when Red  caught me with the crooked cards and  threatened to expose me -- Harolday  shot him.
Why did he kill Clint? An' not me?
That shot was an accident -- it was  meant for you. We planned on getting  the women to let me handle their  business --
(interrupting, furious) -- And do us out of everything -- (moves close to Garvey) You vile -- wicked -- despicable --

She is beside herself in her anger -- and taking up a lar vase sitting nearby, she smashes it to pieces over Garvey head. Garvey goes down unconscious. Miss Martin rushes to her room screaming. Clara follows her.
When he wakes up -- we'll have him  put everything on paper.
Well, you'll have to do the writin' --  'cause I don't know how to write.

head_text.subj: CLARA HURRIES BACK TO THE GROUP FROM UP THE HALL

text: (genuinely concerned) Oh, Mr. Rocklin -- please -- I think  Auntie is out of her mind -- she's  in her room -- laughing.
(grimaces) What that ole pelican needs is a  good spankin'.
(who has been silently  listening) And I'll bet you're just the one who  can do it.
(his eyes flash with  an idea) Yeah -- I believe I am. (looks at the group) I know I am.
He starts away down the hall, rolling up his sleeves.  Rocklin's eyes wander to Clara, who seems quite at a loss Now he moves slowly toward her. In the b.g. Arly watches  Rocklin's every move.
I guess there's no rush for you to  get to Garden City, now --
After a slight pause in which she becomes conscious of Ar Clara speaks.
No -- I don't suppose there's any --  rush --
There is another short pause. Rocklin glances at Arly, an Arly assuming they want to be alone, turns and goes out t door, leaving Julio attending Garvey.
(after Arly goes) If I was like her, I'd stay in the  West.
That means you're goin' back East --  Cousin Clara?
(smiles, nods) It's where I belong -- I know that  now --
It's good to know where you Belong,  I reckon -- Wish I knew.
(wistfully) I can tell you -- you belong with  her --
Rocklin takes it -- a faint smile brushes his face. He tu now and walks out.

Arly is seated on the shaft of an old wagon. The first ra of the morning sun streak through the trees across her as she smiles wistfully down at the antics of a little woodc cavorting on the ground close to her. In a moment Rocklin comes into view in the b.g. He spots Arly, who has her ba to him, and walks over. His approach frightens the woodch away, and turns Arly's head toward him. Neither has anyth to say. Now Rocklin sits beside Arly, but faces the other way.
(after a pause) Thanks.
For what?
Everything.
There is another stilted pause.
(her eyes sweeping  the morning) Beautiful day.
(reflecting) It didn't start out so beautiful.
That's true of lots of things.
Fer instance?
(hesitantly) Well -- you and -- me.
There is another pause. But worlds are being said in the  language of eyes. Their heads move closer and now Rocklin arms sweep around the girl and they kiss.

head_text.subj: GROUNDS NEAR ARLY AND ROCKLIN DAVE AND JULIO HURRYING THR

text: (shouting) Hey, Rock -- Rock -- get out your  pencil and paper --
The two stop abruptly and look o.s.

head_text.subj: ON ROCKLIN AND ARLY KISSING ON DAVE AND JULIO

text: (grimacing) Doggone it -- here Garvey is back in  this world -- an' they're out of it.
